text: A very high airplane view of the entire island. Over this Voice, authoritative, impressive.
In any discussion of contemporary  America and how its people live, we  must inevitably start with --  Manhattan -- New York City, U.S.A!
Manhattan -- glistening, modern giant  of concrete and steel reaching to  the heavens and holding in its arms  seven millions!
Seven millions -- happy beneficiaries  of the advantages and comforts this  gracious metropolis has to offer...
Its fine broad streets and boulevards  facilitate the New Yorker's carefree,  orderly existence.
An enormous traffic jam, horns honking, etc.
Kindly, courteous public servants  ever on hand to offer a word of  friendly advice.
yelling at each other.
A transportation system second to  none in speed and comfort!
Modern recreational facilities for  its children!

head_text.subj: A CROWDED LOWER EAST SIDE STREET

text: Kids playing ball in truck-laden street.
For its adults, the peace and privacy  of a day in the sun!

head_text.subj: CONEY ISLAND ON ITS MOST CROWDED DAY

text: It's delightful changes in climate!

head_text.subj: A BLINDING, WINDSWEPT NEW YORK BLIZZARD

text: Its great institutions of learning!  Open to all. Free of charge.

Leaning on a railing looking down into the excavation are group of sidewalk supervisors. The CAMERA MOVES UP to a H CLOSEUP of one of them. It is Bill Cole (Melvyn Douglas), well-dressed, intelligent, attractive looking young man.

I suppose you're wondering what all  this has to do with Mr. Blandings  and his Dream House? Well, I'll tell  you. Jim Blandings is part of the  fabric of this town. Born and raised  right here, he's as typical a New  Yorker as anyone you'll ever meet.  At least he was. (confidentially) And if you want to know the real  story, I guess I'm your boy. Cole's  my name, Bill Cole. I'm Jim's lawyer  and quote, best friend, unquote.  Jim's one of those bright young men  from Yale. Advertising business,  lovely wife, two fine kids, makes  almost fifteen thousand a year. Want  to know why? Just look up there.
A billboard -- against a white background is a large ham. large letters across the ham is printed:
And below this in quotes: "WHEN YOU'VE GOT THE WHIM, SAY 'WHAM!'"

"When you've got the whim, say  'Wham!'"... Jim Blandings wrote that  slogan. Seven magic words that shine  like a beacon light for the American  housewife! (impressive; almost  reverently) "When you've got the whim, say  'Wham!'" Jim Blandings' contribution  to the American Scene.

location: A LARGE NEW YORK APARTMENT BUILDING

text: As CAMERA MOVES UP it and TOWARD a window:

For fourteen years Jim and Muriel  had been living in their apartment  over on East Seventy-fourth Street.  It was just another of those wonderful  crisp September mornings and the  Blandings were still asleep. Just  like millions of other people in  good old Manhattan -- New York City --  U.S.A.
The CAMERA GOES THROUGH the window and INTO:

Jim (Cary Grant) and Muriel (Myrna Loy) Blandings are asl in twin beds. The room, not large to begin with, gives us the impressio of being cluttered up and overcrowded because the beds,  oversized chest of drawers, dressing table and chaise lou take up an inordinate amount of space. SOUND of an alarm clock going off. Jim awakens, yawns him into hazy consciousness, gropes about on the night table the clock; it isn't there. He slips out of bed, and rubbi his eyes, blindly moves toward the dresser. The circuitou path, which he accomplishes with sleepy dexterity, entail going around the chaise lounge, just missing the ominousl pointed edge of Muriel's dressing table, deftly stepping  over the low dressing table chair and finally reaching th chest of drawers upon which is the clock. He turns off th alarm and yawningly starts back over the same path. We ge the feeling that Jim makes this sleepy excursion every wa morning of his life. Back at his bed, Jim sits down, and, yawning loudly, grop with his feet for his slippers. Before he can find them,  however, he begins to doze off and slowly tilts back towa the pillow, pulling the covers over him. In a moment he i sound asleep. Muriel's arm automatically stretches out an shakes Jim into consciousness. As he painfully reawakens starts to rise, Muriel's arm disappears. We get the impression that this, too, is a regular part o the Blandings' daily routine. Jim locates his slippers, reaches around for his bathrobe can't find it, stumbles his way over to the closet, opens the door.

This is a fairly good-sized closet but it was never inten to be shared by two people, particularly not Jim and Muri Blandings. Assuming that they had started out on even ter it is now obviously Muriel, three-to-one. Her dresses, go slips, seem to obscure his occasional pair of slacks, sui or sports coat. Her shoes neatly line the floor and the s above is loaded to the ceiling with her hat boxes, in an  orderly but somewhat precarious state of balance. Groping blindly for a robe, Jim feels around and pulls on out. As he slips into the arms, we see it's much too smal for him, obviously Muriel's. In disgust he attempts to pu it back. Unable to find a hook he finally jams it in betw two silk dresses which fall to the floor. As he bends dow and gropes for the dresses, he discovers his robe crumple under them on the floor. He drags the robe out and dons i leaving the dresses where they fell. With a guilty look a Muriel he closes the closet door and starts out of the be and into the narrow hall.

A narrow corridor extending the length of the apartment. it are doors leading to the bathroom, the childrens' room and the foyer. Jim shuffles down the hall. He stops at the closed bathro door, listens, hears the shower, knocks.
Okay, dad.
Mm.
Jim continues down the hall, stops at the closed door of children's room, knocks. No sound. He opens the door and  enters.

A small room, crowded and cluttered up with the accoutrem of adolescence. Joan, an eleven-year-old is asleep in one the twin beds. Jim automatically pulls the covers clear o Joan's bed. She awakens, cocks an eye at him.
Okay, dad.
Mm.
As she sleepily stretches and prepares to rise, Jim exits into the hall.

CAMERA FOLLOWS Jim through the foyer into the living room on through the very small combination dining and breakfas nook and into the compact but tiny kitchen. Gussie, the  colored cook, greets him heartily.
'Morning, Mr. Blandings!
(a feeble attempt at  a smile) Mm.

Gussie takes a glass of hot water, squeezes in a little l stirs and hands it to Jim who gulps it down, makes a slig face and pats his stomach. Gussie hands Jim a cup of blac coffee and he starts back toward the bedroom.

Gingerly balancing the cup and saucer, Jim approaches the door to the children's room. With split-second timing, he pauses as the door flies open and Joan, in her bathrobe,  towel in hand, rushes out and past him down the hall. She disappears into the bathroom. Jim carefully proceeds down the hall and, as he reaches the bathroom, deftly steps to the left as the door bursts open and Betsy flies by on th way back to her bedroom. All this is done with a timing a shifting of hips of which Knute Rockne might have been pr Jim continues down the hall, enters the bedroom.
Muriel is still asleep as Jim enters, walks over, nudges  her.
Muriel.
Mm?
Coffee.
Muriel awakens, sniffs the fresh coffee, smiles, sits up, takes the cup.
Thank you, dear.

They kiss briefly. Muriel starts to sip the coffee as Jim goes to his chest of drawers. It consists of several rows small drawers above and large drawers below. Jim ruffles  through a couple of small drawers, pulls out a suit of  underwear, continues noisily and with some annoyance to l through the other drawers.
Looking for something, dear?
(briefly) My socks.
Why don't you look in your sock  drawer?
(with restraint) That's where I found my underwear.
Oh. (brightly) Well, try your underwear drawer.
I'm in my underwear drawer.
He reaches in and holds up one of Muriel's silk slips.
(sipping coffee) Well, they must be somewhere. (attempt at morning  cheeriness) Socks just don't get up and walk  away by themselves.
(strained patience) Muriel, I thought the top two-and-a- half drawers were to be mine! I wish  you'd tell Gussie --
The closet! That's where they are.  We put them in the closet.
Socks? In the closet?
Well, there didn't seem to be any  room in the drawers...
And there's so much of it in the  closet!
...so Gussie and I decided that from  now on we'll keep them in a basket  on the shelf.
Well, thanks a lot!

He strides angrily to the closet, opens the door, reaches for the basket and pulls it off the shelf. As he does so, all the hat boxes come tumbling down knocking the basket  from his hand, the socks spilling on the floor. About to  explode, he looks at Muriel.
Jim, I do wish you'd make an effort  to be a little less clumsy.
(barely containing  himself) I'll try, dear.

Jim looks at her barely containing himself, and then puts the hats back in the boxes, jams them back on the shelf w they toter precariously. With bated breath he gingerly cl the closet door. Pause. Silence. He picks up a pair of so and walks cautiously toward the hall door. Suddenly there a rumble and crash from inside the closet. Jim exchanges look with Muriel, is about to say something, changes his  mind, exits into the hall. Muriel looks at the closet, si takes another sip of coffee.
Jim opens the door of the bathroom. There is a scream. He quickly closes the door, scowling with annoyance. A momen later the door opens and Joan emerges, wrapping her robe  around her.
(sharply) Father, just one morning I wish you'd  knock!
(to her back as she  walks away) 'Morning, dear.
Joan disappears into her room as Jim enters the bathroom.

Very small with a stall shower. Jim takes off his bathrob yawns, gets on the scale, looks at the dial, shakes his h He takes a deep breath, draws in his stomach, looks down, scowls, shrugs, gets off, moves to the mirror. He examine the thinness of his hair, the condition of his tongue, et Taking his toothbrush he looks down at the tube he is abo to use, frowns.
WHAT HE SEES - the toothpaste tube. It has been squeezed the middle, one of Blandings' pet peeves.

head_text.subj: JIM METICULOUSLY SMOOTHES OUT THE TUBE

text: CLOSE SHOT - Jim meticulously smoothes out the tube, roll up the used portion from the bottom. Then placing a small amount on his brush, he caps the tube, and starts vigorou to brush his teeth. As he does so, he attempts with his f hand, to put the tube back in the medicine cabinet which opens.
CLOSE SHOT - the medicine cabinet, loaded to the hilt wit medical accumulation of fourteen years of family life.

CLOSE SHOT - Jim. As he pushes the tube into the bulging shelf, a bottle of iodine falls out. Jim makes a desperat one-handed catch, still brushing his teeth. As he pushes iodine into the second shelf, a small bottle of pills pop out. Jim catches it, pushes it back into the cabinet. A b of cough medicine falls out. He catches it, tries to put back, finds it won't fit. He looks at the bottle, sniffs contemplates its value, throws it in the wastebasket. He  finishes washing his mouth, admires his teeth, disrobes a steps into the shower, putting on his shower cap. He reac scowls, takes off the cap and turns it upside down, a ful cup of water falling out. He reaches out for a towel, dri the inside of the cap, carefully puts it back on his now hair. Then he turns the water on and at the first warm sp Jim Blandings' life takes a sharp turn for the better. He starts to sing, a robust bathroom baritone version of "Ho On The Range."

Jim - He stands in front of the washstand lathering his f Over scene we hear Muriel's voice from the shower. She is singing a lusty chorus of "Home On The Range." Jim picks his razor and turns to the mirror. He reacts with annoyan as he discovers it is covered with steam. With weary  resignation he takes a towel and starts to rub off the mi As he clears one section another clouds up. By the time h gets it all reasonably clear he finds that his lather nee freshening. He grimly relathers his face only to find tha the mirror is again clouded up. As he turns with exaspera toward the shower we see Muriel turn off the water, reach for a towel, start to dry herself. The mirror cleared off, Jim relathers, starts to shave. D this, Muriel, having dried herself and donned her robe, c into scene.
(reaching for  toothbrush) Excuse...
She takes her toothbrush and then opens the cabinet to ge the paste. Jim, automatically following the mirror, has t squeeze around in a desperately contorted position as he  continues shaving.
CLOSE SHOT - Muriel. She takes the tube from the cabinet  and, squeezing the tube in the middle, applies the paste her brush.
Jim and Muriel - Placing the tube on the washstand, Murie closes the cabinet. Jim, still shaving, moves back to his original position as he follows the mirror.
Excuse...

Muriel nods, steps back, starts to brush her teeth. They  both hum "Home On The Range". Her mouth full, Muriel taps Jim on the shoulder. Without stopping his shaving, Jim mo to one side as Muriel rinses her mouth. She examines her  face in the mirror.
(impatiently) If you don't mind, dear.
As he steps back in front of the mirror, Muriel continues look at her face in the glass, over his shoulder. She dec she needs a little skin lotion.
(as she steps in front  of him) Sorry.
She again opens the cabinet. Jim once more follows the mi around, nicks his face, gives up, stands glaring arms fol Muriel takes the lotion from the cabinet.
Moment, dear.
Take your time. I can spare the blood.
(looks up) Oh... cut yourself?
I cut myself every morning. I kind  of look forward to it.
Why don't you get an electric razor?
(trying to shave) Don't like them. No close shave.
Ridiculous! Bill Cole's been using  one for years.
He doesn't have my beard!
That's silly. Bill's beard is just  as tough and coarse and --
(irritably) I'm not interested in discussing the  grain and texture of Bill Cole's  hair follicles before I've had my  orange juice.
You don't have to carry on so. I  only said, why don't you get an  electric razor?
Because I prefer the cool, clean  sweep of the tempered steel as it  glides smoothly --
Stop writing advertising copy! Hurry  up, dear, you'll be late for  breakfast.

Muriel exits. Jim sighs, turns back to the mirror and wit few deft strokes finishes shaving. As he reaches for the  water faucet, he encounters the tube of toothpaste, squee in the middle. Reacting with annoyance, he meticulously  smoothes it out and rolls it up from the bottom. He opens the cabinet and gingerly places the tube on the top shelf The iodine bottle pops out. He grimly catches it, studies his problem, has a solution. With his right hand he start slowly to close the mirror door. Just before it closes, h slips the bottle into the cabinet with his left hand, qui slamming the mirror door, trapping the bottle. He reacts  masterfully at his triumph, picks up his robe and starts the door. As he reaches it, there is the SOUND of the cab opening and a crash as the bottle obviously hits the  washstand. As Jim winces,

Narrow and small. The four Blandings are at breakfast, Ji and Muriel each reading his section of the morning paper, Betsy pasting a clipping in her notebook, Joan engrossed a magazine of popular science. As we come in, Gussie, tak off the orange juice, is squeezing by Jim who accordingly and automatically ducks his head as she passes. Jim  uncomfortably turns the newspaper to another page, folds reacts with pained but controlled exasperation.
...Who did this?
INSERT NEWSPAPER, a section of which has been cut out. BACK TO SCENE.
(very matter-of-factly) I did.
She holds out her hand to Joan, who, automatically, and  without looking up hands her the salt.
I have repeatedly told you -- (ducking as Gussie  comes back with coffee) -- don't cut up the morning paper  until I've had a chance to look at  it!
I'm sorry, father. It's necessary  research.
She hands the salt back to Joan who automatically passes to Muriel.
(with some sarcasm) I suppose this is another of Miss  Stellwagon's so-called Progressive  Projects?

(using salt and handing  it to Jim) Now dear, there just isn't any point  in sending your children to an  expensive school if you're going to  undermine the teacher's authority in  your own dining room.
I'm not undermining anything. I happen  to be in the advertising business  and keeping abreast of the times is  important to me.
And so is your children's education.
That's not the point.
It certainly is.
It certainly is not!
(without looking up  from her magazine) Bicker, bicker, bicker.
You eat your cornflakes!
Jim ducks as Gussie passes back on her way to the kitchen
(handing Joan toast) Joan, every time your father and I  have a lively discussion we aren't  necessarily bickering. (to Betsy; solicitously) What is it, dear, another English  composition?

(taking toast from  Joan) Miss Stellwagon has assigned each of  us to take a want ad and write a  human interest theme about it. (to Jim; passing toast  to him) I found one typical of the  disintegration of our present society.
(taking toast, not  looking up from his  paper) I wasn't aware of the fact that our  society was disintegrating.

I didn't expect you to be, father.  Miss Stellwagon says that middle- class people like us are all too  prone to overlook the pressures and  tensions which befall the less  fortunate members of our community.
Jim puts down the paper, turns to Muriel.
(with great restraint) Muriel, I know it's asking a lot,  but just one morning I would like to  sit down and have breakfast without  social significance!
Picks up his paper.
Jim, you really might take a little  more interest in your children's  education.
(without looking up) You can't squeeze blood from a turnip.
Jim reacts with painful resignation, folds his arms, puts down the paper, turns slowly to Betsy.
All right. All right. I'll listen.
(picking up her  scrapbook) It's just twenty-four words. But in  simple eloquence it mirrors a minor  tragedy of our times.
(quietly) Well?...

(reading) "Forced to sell. Farm dwelling, oak  grove, apple orchard, trout stream,  hay fields, four barns, seclusion,  superb view, original beams, paved  highway, acreage... (with emotion) Will sacrifice..."
Pause.
Go on.
(simply) That's all.
That's all?!
You don't see it, do you, father?
No. Fellow wants to sell a house so  he puts an ad in the paper. What did  you expect him to do, take it to the  United Nations!
There must be more to it than that. (to Betsy) Isn't there, dear?

Certainly, mother. What some people  don't see is the whole sordid picture.  A poor, honest farmer, pushed to the  wall by hardship, soil erosion,  mortgages, everybody gobbling,  gobbling, gobbling, until finally,  in desperation, he is "forced to  sell," and stoops to the crass  commercialism of newspaper  advertising.
(muttering) Oh, indeed... crass commercialism...  advertising...
(nose in her magazine) Miss Stellwagon says advertising is  a basically parasitic profession.
(with extreme control) Oh, she does?
Miss Stellwagon says that advertising  makes people who can't afford it buy  things they don't want with money  they haven't got.

(elaborate sarcasm) Perhaps your Miss Stellwagon is right.  Perhaps I ought to get out of this  "basically parasitic profession,"  which at the moment is paying for  her very fancy tuition, those extra  French lessons, her progressive summer  camp and for that matter, the very  braces on your teeth!
I wish you wouldn't discuss money in  front of the children.
Why not, they spend enough of it!
Bicker, bicker, bicker.
As Jim gives her a look and buries himself in his paper, downstairs buzzer rings. Gussie enters, squeezes by Jim w automatically ducks, goes to the phone in b.g.
Hello. Who? (calls) Miss Blandings, there's a Mr.  Funkhauser wants to see you.
Funkhauser? (remembers) Oh, Mr. Funkhauser!
That's what he says.
Muriel looks nervously at Jim who is preoccupied, reading his paper. Then she turns back to Gussie.
Uh -- better ask him to come up.
(into phone) Says to come up.
Gussie hangs up, squeezes by Jim, exits into the kitchen. Pause.
(tentatively) Oh -- uh -- darling, Mr. Funkhauser's  here.
(looking up) ...Who?
You remember, Bunny Funkhauser, that  clever young interior decorator we  met at the Collins' cocktail party?
(distastefully) What's he doing here?
(nervously) Well, I imagine he's brought the --  uh -- estimates.
(blankly) ...Estimates?

(rapidly; to conceal  a feeling of guilt) Darling, you know how long we've  said we've got to do something about  this apartment, and, well, he called  last week, and I had him come over,  and he's got some simply wonderful  ideas!
(quietly) There couldn't be two Bunny  Funkhausers, could there?
Why, no, dear.
Then this is the same clever young  man who's responsible for that zebra- striped monstrosity in the Collins'  living room?
That couch is terribly functional.
Phil Collins told me what he paid  for all that function! (angrily) If you think I'm going to --
SOUND of doorbell ringing.
Darling, please! (changing subject) Children, you'll be late to school.  Run along and --
The children rise, pick up their school paraphernalia.
Miss Stellwagon says that  functionalism in modern furniture --
Never mind, dear.
She hustles Betsy and Joan toward the foyer as Jim rises.

Gussie has just admitted Mr. Funkhauser. He is a tall,  slender, effete-looking, young man. He is loaded down wit sketches, samples of wallpaper, bolts of material. Betsy Joan brush by him on their way out.
Good morning.
(with a sharp  appraising look) Hi.
As they rush out and the door closes, Jim and Muriel ente scene.
Good morning, Mr. Funkhauser. You  remember Mr. Blandings?
But of course.
He sweeps by them into the living room, taking over  completely.

You'll have to pardon my bursting in  at this dreary hour -- (puts a sketch on a  chair) -- practically the middle of the  night -- (puts wallpaper against  mantel) -- but I did so want to catch you  in. I've been at it hammer and tongs  all week and I'm just a mess -- (drapes bolt of chintz  over high-backed  chair) -- but then Muriel and I thought we  ought to talk it over with you before  we take the plunge...

Funkhauser looks briefly for a high object over which to  display his last bolt of chintz, finds none, settles for  Jim's shoulder over which he drapes the cloth, the folds  flowing down in front. As Jim reacts:
(smoothing out folds  on the chintz) After all, it's your home, too, and  it should reflect you. You know,  Man's Castle, all that sort of thing.
Jim looks down at the chintz.
(ominously) Muriel!
(quickly) Jim, just wait till you hear. He's  got some wonderful ideas for the  foyer.

Oh, that's out! All out! Changed the  whole thing! I just couldn't live  with it! I said to myself, "Bunny,  what are the Blandings? How shall we  do them?" And the answer was perfectly  obvious. Very American, very grass  roots, very blueberry pie -- that  sort of thing.
(dark look at Muriel) Mm.
Funkhauser fingers the material of a drape, disdainfully  removes his hand.
Now first, let's dig into this living  room of yours, it's really a dreary.
(quickly; to Jim) We want this room to be very gay,  dear. Something in bright reds,  yellows and greens.
(appalled) Red, yellow and green?!
Oh, come, Mr. Blandings, let's not  run away from color.
Not running away -- (a lame joke) -- just backing off a little.

Uh -- yes. (brightly) Now as I see our room, it's definitely  Colonial. You know, cobbler's bench,  breakfront, pie cooler, student lamp,  hooked rug. But everything in good  taste. It must not jump out at you  and scream: "Look -- see how antique  I am!"
Heaven forbid.
Of course, these things take  imagination. You've simply got to be  able to visualize.
(politely, removing  chintz) If you'll forgive me, Mr. Funkhauser,  what I'd like to visualize -- at  this dreary hour -- is how much is  this all going to cost?
Well, really, I hesitate to say.  After all -- (indicates) -- by the time this wall is out we  may find --
(reacting) This wall is -- what?
Out. Source of light is from the  east. Obviously if our room is to  have any function at all --
You're going to tear out the wall?!
Dear, it's a wonderful notion.
Visualize three feet of leaded panes,  the rest --
Can you give me a figure?
Well! Costs aren't what they used to  be, you know, and --
Just a figure.
Materials are impossible, labor has  just run wild --
Just an overall figure.
Well!... I shouldn't like to be tied  down. But I suppose if you must have  a figure, I'd say -- mm -- (lightly) -- somewhere in the neighborhood of  seven.
Mm... Seven.
(nodding) Mm.
That would be seven... thousand?
Mm.
Jim looks at Muriel, considers.

(soberly) We-ll. That seems fair. (gathering up materials) After all, we're not running away  from color -- (picks up wallpaper) -- and we are tearing out walls -- (picks up sketches) Mr. Funkhauser, do you have a card?
Jim, we haven't even discussed the  rest of the house.
We will, dear. (leads the whole batch  on Funkhauser)
(huffy) Well, really, I --
(deftly steering him  toward the door) We'll talk it all out and then we'll  get in touch with Bunny.
CAMERA TRUCKS with them to the door.
Well, really, I mean, I was under  the impression we'd come to some  decision today.
I'm sure we will.
We-ll!
So nice of you to come. (puts Funkhauser's  hat on his head) Good day.
And Funkhauser is gone. Jim closes the door, turns ominou
(apprehensively) Now darling, you -- you just don't  go to a man like Funkhauser and ask  how much it's going to cost before  you even know what he's going to do!
No, that would be too logical! Seven  thousand dollars! Blueberry pie! I  wouldn't put seventy-five cents into  this broken-down rat trap!
(sentimentally) It's our home, Jim. Betsy was  practically born in this apartment.
That does not make it a national  shrine! (vehemently) Seven thousand dollars and not one  word about closets.
Closets! You wouldn't even let him  get to the bathroom!
I haven't got that kind of money!
The way you talk, Jim Blandings,  you'd think I was some kind of  congenital idiot!
Sometimes I'm beginning to wonder!
(furious) You can just get out of here!
That's not a bad idea!

He angrily jerks open the hall closet door, pulls his hat down from the shelf, several hat boxes, some ski boots an tennis racket tumbling down on his head. Jim jams his hat onto his head, takes a deep breath and storms out, slammi the door. Muriel walks over to the closet, is about to be down and pick up a hatbox when all of her pent-up emotion explode. She kicks the hat box into the closet, slams the door, starts to cry.
Exiting from the elevator, Jim enters a door marked:

On the wall are various framed copies of Jim's handiwork. Most prominent are advertisements for a meat product call "Wham!" "A Whale of a Ham!" There is ample evidence of th fact that Jim's most successful slogan is: "When you've g the Whim - say 'Wham!'" Jim enters, goes to his desk, sits down, still emotionall upset. He glances at a photograph of Muriel, looks guilti away, then back.
(to photograph) Sorry.
His secretary enters.
Good morning, Mr. Blandings.
(briefly) 'Morning.
You wanted to see the color copy  from this month's House and Stream.
She hands him a magazine. He looks at it perfunctorily, i about to hand it back when his eye is caught by an ad on back cover.

INSERT THE BACK COVER - A community and extolling life in the country, sponsored by a group of realtors, local cham of commerce etc. Over a pastoral scene of lovely little h checkering a rolling landscape are the words:

head_text.subj: LIVE IN THE COUNTRY COME TO PEACEFUL CONNECTICUT TRADE CI

text: In smaller type:

head_text.subj: CHOOSE YOUR OWN COMMUTING TIME HOUSES OLD AND NEW... ACRE

text: Over this:
Will that be all?
Jim - Mary.
(looking up; blankly) Hm?
Will that be all?
Without answering he turns back to the ad. The CAMERA COM IN for a HEAD CLOSEUP as he studies the ad and on the sou track we hear:
"Forced to sell. Farm dwelling, oak  grove, apple orchard, trout stream,  hay fields, four barns, original  beams --"
As he looks up thoughtfully:
It is a convertible, the top down. Jim is driving through Manhattan.
Well, that's the way it all started.  The ad was enough to convince Jim --
Jim and Muriel - They are leaving Manhattan, entering the Merritt Parkway. Muriel, wearing an orchid corsage, looks curiously at Jim. His answering gesture says, "Just wait see." Over this:
-- But Muriel was a little tougher.  I guess the corsage did it.

Jim, Muriel and Mr. Smith - They are driving through a  beautiful Connecticut countryside. Mr. Smith, a local rea estate dealer, is of that shrewd Yankee breed which  specializes in the understatement, underselling school of salesmanship.

There they are, two little fish from  New York -- out in the deep deep  waters of Connecticut real estate.  That's Smith, the real estate  salesman. Mighty shrewd cookie in a  quiet sort of way. Never thought  he'd get a bite this quick.
Smith looks speculatively at the Blandings.
Now he's sizing up the catch. "Mm.  Let's see. Convertible -- orchids --  must be pretty well fixed. Wonder if  they're lookers or buyers?"
Jim takes a deep breath, looks at Muriel as if to say, "G that air!" Muriel smiles with approval. Jim pats her hand affectionately. Smith reacts.
They're buyers. (confidentially) Yes, sir, Smith, looks like you're  finally going to unload the old  Hackett place. Now first thing is  get 'em a little anxious.

Jim slows down the car as they approach a rather pictures looking old Connecticut farmhouse. He and Muriel react wi approval, look questioningly at Smith. Smith shakes his h "no," as though to say, "Not nearly good enough for you."
Th-a-a-t's right!
Jim, Muriel, Mr. Smith - They pass another house. Jim and Muriel appraise it with interest, look at Smith.
Uh-uh, not yet.
Smith firmly shakes his head "no."
Jim, Muriel and Mr. Smith - Another house.
Take it easy, Smith, give 'em a little  more line.
Smith shakes his head "no".
Jim, Muriel and Mr. Smith - The car pulls to a stop.
Now we're ready to gaff 'em.
(proudly) Well, folks, there she is -- the old  Hackett Place.
The Blandings look off, react with interest and approval.

What they see -- Burrowed into the upward slope of the la is the old Hackett farmhouse. If the roof seems to sway a little and the massive stone chimney to tilt a bit and th overall condition of board and beam to be a trifle unstea charge it up to age, which will be a hundred and seventy  years come next April. However, the overall effect is  definitely one of picturesque rustic beauty. In the back a series of barns and behind them the rolling hills known Bald Mountain.
Fifty mighty pretty little acres...
(involuntarily) It's simply charming!
Jim's look cautions against her over-enthusiasm.
That is, for an old house.
(casually) Of course, you understand, Mr. Smith,  we're just window shopping, so to  speak. Nothing really definite in  mind.
Perfectly all right.
(studies house; with  assumed indifference) Mm. Not a bad-looking place, but  it's certainly a lot older than  anything we had in mind.
She's no spring chicken -- (sagely) -- but that's just what makes her  such a buy.
They look at him curiously. Smith's attitude is matter-of fact, almost without enthusiasm.
This isn't just old timber, or a  virgin stand oak grove other side of  the trout stream, or a couple of  fruit orchards... You're buying a  piece of American history.
(interested in spite  of himself) You don't say! How's that?
First year she was built, General  Gates stopped right here to water  his horses.
(impressed) Oh! Old General Gates -- Civil War.
Revolutionary War.
Oh. Oh, that General Gates. Hear  that, honey, General Gates!
(with concern) Wouldn't that make the house over a  hundred years old?
(proudly) Hundred and seventy come next April.
The Blandings exchange a doubtful look which Smith catche

Now I'm not trying to sell you  anything -- all I'm saying is that  one of these days someone with a  little vision and imagination's goin'  to come along, and just steal this  place -- (confidentially) and I mean steal it.
The Blandings, as one, turn to the house with renewed  interest. This is not lost on Smith.
Mr. Blandings, I know you can look  at that house and just about picture  what a couple of coats of paint and  a little pointing up here and there  can do to it.
Mm.
The CAMERA MOVES TO a HEAD CLOSEUP of Jim as he begins to visualize

WHAT HE SEES - The Old Hackett Place suddenly DISSOLVES i the New Blandings' Place -- Jim's version. It is a lovely country house. Massive. Masculine. Jim, in jodhpurs, twee coat, pipe and accompanied by two large Irish Setters, is proudly surveying his property. He nonchalantly holds a s beautiful shotgun in the most precisely correct position. CLOSE SHOT - JIM'S FACE. CLOSE SHOT - Jim's face. His lips don't move but we hear voice.
Hm. Wonder what he meant by "steal?"
And I guess I don't have to tell  you, Mrs. Blandings, what a woman's  touch could do to a place like this.
Well --
CAMERA MOVES to a HEAD CLOSEUP of Muriel as she starts to visualize.

WHAT SHE SEES - The Old Hackett Place DISSOLVES into a da feminine cottage with criss-cross curtains at the window a lovely little white rail fence enclosing "her garden."  Muriel, in delightful gingham, is in the garden, admiring her latest triumph - the largest rose ever grown in Lansd County. CLOSE SHOT - MURIEL'S FACE. CLOSE SHOT - Muriel's face. Her face is soft. Her lips do move but we hear:
It is a nice old house. It just needs  someone to love it, that's all.
Yes, sir, you've certainly got to  visualize.
CAMERA MOVES to a HEAD CLOSEUP of Smith as he, too, begin to visualize. WHAT HE SEES - THE OLD HACKETT PLACE. WHAT HE SEES - The Old Hackett Place. Suddenly SUPERIMPOS over it in large figures is:

head_text.subj: SMITH LOOKS AT HIM AND MURIEL

text: GROUP SHOT - Smith looks at Him and Muriel who are lookin at the house with unabashed affection. Jim's arm goes ten around Muriel's waist. Smith looks back at the house. WHAT HE SEES - THE OLD HACKETT PLACE. WHAT HE SEES - The Old Hackett Place. The
is quickly replaced by:
(brightly) Shall we go up and take a look at  her?
(a little too casual) Well -- I -- suppose as long as we're  here...
(same) I guess it doesn't hurt to take a  look.
As Smith precedes them up the path toward the house:
(sotto) It does have possibilities. Do you  think we can get it?
(sotto) Like taking candy from a baby.
(same) Now don't lose your head.
(same) Shh. Just keep quiet and let me handle  this.
As they enter the house:
Tell me, Smith, what kind of a price  is the owner asking for this old  place?
Jim and Muriel precede Smith as they exit from the house. Jim and Muriel carry on a sotto voce conversation, Smith  looks off with some concern in the direction of the road.
It's wonderful, Jim! That master  bedroom with those two closets!
Shh!
Funkhauser could do wonders with  this --
(firmly) Funkhauser will have nothing to do  with this house! Shh!
Smith's face suddenly brightens as a weatherbeaten old ca appears, turns up the driveway, stops.
(calling) Hi, George!
Hi, Eph! (to the Blandings;  feigned surprise) What do you know, it's Eph Hackett,  owner of the place!
(pleased) Well, you don't say.
Eph Hackett gets out of the car, saunters over. Hackett i middle-aged, rural-looking, taciturn New Englander
Eph, this is Mr. and Mrs. Blandings --  from New York City.
Howdy.
How do you do?
You certainly have a lovely place  here, Mr. Hackett.
(briefly) Ye-ap.
(pleasantly) Mr. Hackett, we've just been talking  to Smith here about -- uh -- taking  the old place off your hands.
Hackett exchanges the briefest of looks with Smith who al imperceptibly shakes his head "no."
(firmly) Ain't for sale!
As the Blandings react with dismay:
(smoothly) Why don't you folks just go out in  back and take a look at the orchard?
He gives them a wink which says, "Just leave it to me." T Blandings exchange a look, turn and walk off.
How'm I doin', George?
Nice timin', Eph. Think we got  something here.
They the same people you showed it  to in nineteen-thirty-eight?
They were lookers -- this is the  real thing.
If they got five thousand dollars on  'em. don't let 'em get away.
They already offered ten.
(mildly) Y'don't say... What's my asking price?
Fifteen...
A mite stiff...
I've got 'em measured. (mellower) They're gonna take the place for -- (turns, looks back at  house) eleven thousand.
Make it eleven thousand five hundred  fifty.
Odd kind of figure.
Might as well take the commission  out of them instead of me.
As Smith raises a knowing eyebrow:
Muriel and the two children are having breakfast. Jim ent in high spirits. During this scene we repeat the business passing, etc. used in the previous breakfast scene.
(singing gaily to  "Home On The Range") "Home, home in Connecticut With a  closet to hang up your petticut..."
(as he seats himself) ...Jim?
(going on, as he places  his napkin in his  lap) "No hustle or fuss No Fifth Avenue  bus --"
Uh -- Jim?
Hm?
I was just wondering, dear. Ten  thousand dollars is such an awful  lot to offer --
Jim looks suspiciously at her, at the children, then back her.
That is, for two people who don't  know anything at all about real  estate, or anything... (Jim's look darkens) I mean, don't you think perhaps we  should have asked someone's  professional advice?
Like... say... a lawyer?
Well, Bill knows about these things  and --
Muriel, for once in my life I'm going  to make one small decision, on my  own, without the legalistic  machinations of Mr. Bill Cole.
It seems very peculiar that when  your very best friend happens to be  one of the very cleverest young  lawyers in New York City --
Muriel, I don't want to hear another  word about Bill Cole! (turns to children) Well, did your mother tell you about  the house?
Yes.
Well?
Miss Stellwagon says the current  craze for modernizing old farmhouses  is a form of totem worship.
(with great restraint) Did it ever occur to you two that  there may be some remote, intangible  subjects upon which your Miss Irma  Stellwagon is not the final authority?
Why don't we buy a Solaxion house?
...You know it's just barely  conceivable -- What kind of a house?
Solaxion. It's built on a mast like  a tent and it revolves with the sun.
Oh, it... revolves... with the sun?
That's right.
Who lives next door -- Buck Rogers?!
It's the only practical way to live.  When a new model comes out you trade  the old one in like a used car.
(plaintively) Muriel --
Children, you haven't even seen this  house yet.
Personally, I'd like a Crane Mobile  home. It comes all folded up and all  you do is plug it in for electricity  and water and --

Now just a minute! (to Muriel) What kind of children are these? (to girls) Do you want to spend the rest of  your lives in chromium tents and  portable merry-go-rounds? This house  was built before our country became  a nation. It has dignity. It's --  it's --
Gussie enters with a letter.
(handing it to Jim) Special delivery, Mr. Blandings.
(with suppressed;  excitement) From Smith!
As he eagerly opens it and reads, his face falls.
Mm.
Well?
(reading) "I have conveyed your offer of ten  thousand dollars to Mr. Hackett and  am sorry to say he is not interested.  However, I feel..."
Oh, dear. Maybe we should have gone  a few dollars higher.
(stoutly) He's bluffing. Simple as that.
For ten thousand dollars we could  get a Rockford Trailer and a Zamboni  Power Unit. It's kitchen, bathroom  and air conditioning all rolled up  into --
Jim gives her a weary look, turns to Muriel.
(firmly) Muriel, I'll let him push me to ten  thousand, two hundred, but not a  penny more!

INSERT JIM'S COST CHART - Rising diagonally and bisecting the chart is a line graduated in scale starting at $5000 running up to around $17,000. Resting on the line at exac $10,000 is a miniature of the old house. Fluttering acros the scene from left to right is a letter from Smith on th stationery of the Lansdale Realty Co. As we see the letter and hear the voice of Smith, miniatu figures of Smith and Hackett appear at the lower side of house. Their shoulders start pushing the house up the  graduated scale. Over this:
"Dear Mr. Blandings: While your offer  of ten thousand two hundred is still  not acceptable to Ephemus Hackett -- "
A letter on Danton & Bascomb's stationery flutters across the screen from right to left. A miniature figure of Jim  appears above the house, desperately pushing it back. Ove this, we hear:
"Dear Mr. Smith: You may inform Mr.  Hackett that the very highest I could  possibly go --"
As a succession of letters flutter across the screen, fir from left to right and then from right to left, and the h is jockeyed back and forth, they are punctuated with the  following lines:
"Dear Friend Blandings --"
"My dear Friend Smith --"
"Dear Blandings --!"
"Dear Smith - !"

Throughout this Smith's voice remains bland and unperturb while Jim's has the desperate, frenetic quality of a man  being slowly pushed to the wall. The Special Effect concludes with the house finally and f at rest on the preordained $11,550. As the antagonists on both sides of the house relax, Smith reaches around in fr of the house and shakes hands with Jim. It's a deal! About halfway through when the going gets tough, Jim beck Muriel to help in the losing fight. As they now embrace,  Smith and Hackett shake hands in mutual congratulation.
Door - on it is printed:

A successful lawyer's office, the walls crowded with leat bound books. Jim and Muriel are seated facing the large d behind which sits Bill Cole. Bill finishes reading a seri of papers, the sum total of correspondence between Jim an Mr. Smith. He sets down the papers, leans back thoughtful Jim and Muriel look at him with nervous but eager  anticipation.
(not too sure) What do you think, Bill? Steal, huh?
(drily) It certainly is.
Jim looks triumphantly at Muriel.
Perhaps "steal" is an understatement --  "swindle" might be a little more  appropriate.
(with pride) Well, it wasn't much, Bill. I just  saw a good thing and I -- (take) What do you mean?

Every time you get a little tight  you weep on my shoulder about the  advertising business and how it forces  a sensitive soul like yourself to  make a living by bamboozling the  American public. (picks up Smith's  correspondence) I would say that a small part of  this victimized group has now  redressed the balance.
What are you talking about?
You! You've been taken to the cleaners  and you don't even know your pants  are off!
Dear, I told you. I said we should  call Bill --
Never mind, Muriel! (to Bill; challengingly) All right, just what's wrong with  this deal?
First time around you offered ten  thousand dollars for fifty acres,  right?
What of it?

That's two hundred dollars an acre.  I know that part of Connecticut and  one hundred dollars an acre is  standard top-gouge price to city  slickers. When the natives sell to  each other it's around forty or less.
Forty dollars an acre!
The man's entitled to a fair profit.
Not two hundred and eighty-four  percent. (indicates papers) And besides, you're not getting fifty  acres, you're only getting thirty- five, more or less.
Where does it say that?
(picks up letter) I refer to a rather obscure post- script on the back of the second  letter from Friend Smith.
He hands the letter to Muriel.

(reading) "Incidentally, Mr. Hackett has been  a little over-optimistic about the  acreage. It will probably survey  somewhere in the neighborhood of  thirty-five acres, more or less, but  I feel sure..."
(on the defensive) All right, so it's thirty-five! What's  the difference? Do you know how many  tennis courts you can get on thirty- five acres?
You're not spending eleven thousand  five hundred dollars for tennis  courts!
That's not the point!

(very businesslike) That's precisely the point. We're  going to write this Hackett a strong  letter and tell him he can either  kick in with those fifteen acres,  reduce the price, or find another  sucker.
(rising emotion) We'll do no such thing! I'm not going  to queer this deal over fifteen broken- down acres!
(to Bill) We were just going window shopping  and so far it's cost us eleven  thousand five hundred dollars and  they even made us pay the commission!
You don't understand business.
You mean extortion.
As Jim turns on Bill and is about to answer him explosive
(thoughtfully) I wonder if we could get another two  year lease on the apartment?
(heatedly) Now wait a minute! You can't measure  everything on a slide rule. This  house has certain intangibles.
Like what, for instance?
Like antique value, for instance! It  just so happens that General Gates  stopped right there, at that very  house, to water his horses.
I don't care if General Grant dropped  in for a scotch and soda -- you're  still getting rocked!
That was a different war!
I think Bill's absolutely right.

(struggling to contain  himself; quietly) Let me explain something. To both of  you. For fifteen years I've been  cooped up in a four room cracker  box! Just getting shaved in the  morning entitles a man to the  Congressional Medal for bravery.
That doesn't make this a good buy.

Bill -- Muriel and I have found what  I am not ashamed to call our Dream  House. It's like a fine painting.  You buy it with your heart, not your  head. You don't ask, how much was  the canvas, how much was the paint?  You look at it and you say, "It's  beautiful... I want it," and if it  costs a few pennies more you pay it --  and gladly -- because you love it  and you can't measure the things you  love in dollars and cents!
Muriel looks at Jim, impressed, her face softening with  compassion.

(emotionally spent) Well -- that's how I feel about this  place. And when I sign those papers  Saturday, I can look the world in  the face and say, "It's mine! My  house! My home! My thirty-five acres!"
(coming over; moved,  touched) Our house. Our home. Our thirty-five  acres...
They tenderly kiss.
...more or less...
On Jim's reaction:
Comprehensive Shot showing village green of a small, typi quaint New England town.

Old Judge Quarles is reading from the title deed, the  proceedings almost over. Jim stands in front of the bench flanked by Muriel and Bill. Mr. Smith and Hackett are the only other people present. As the Judge drones on, Jim an Muriel exchange a smile. Jim squeezes her hand intimately

(reading) "...thence along said stonewall fence  forming the East boundary of said  Lansdale Road, N 20 27' E, 21.84  feet to the end of said stonewall  fence, thence along a wire fence, N  16 31' W, 78.66 feet to a dead twenty- inch chestnut tree, thence westward  to said stonewall fence, to a total  of thirty-one and a half acres --"
(reacting) What was that? How many acres?
Judge Quarles looks up impatiently at the interruption.
(precisely) Thirty-one and a half.
(to Hackett) I was under the impression your  property was thirty-five acres, Mr.  Hackett.
It is... more or less.
Bill looks significantly at Jim.
You see, Mr. Blandings, when you  signed the purchase agreement it was  subject to traced map attached.  Surveyed to an even thirty-one and a  half acres.
Jim turns to Bill for affirmation. Bill soberly nods his  head, "yes."
Anything wrong?
It's nothing, Your Honor, just a few  less tennis courts.
Jim gives Bill a sour look as the Judge continues:
(with ministerial  resonance) "...to have and to hold to him, the  said Grantee, his heirs and assigns  to his and their own proper use and  benefit forever."
During this, and as a shaft of sunlight hits them, a beat look comes across the faces of Jim and Muriel. For a mome it has become their wedding day. After a momentary pause:
(very businesslike) Subject to a six thousand dollar  mortgage held by Ephemus Whittaker  Hackett...
As the Blandings are startled back to grim reality:
LONG SHOT - The Blandings' car. The Blandings and Bill Co driving along. They approach a fork in the road which lea to a very old covered New England bridge. On the bridge i sign which reads:
They pause, turn, go through the bridge.
As they drive through the dark interior of the bridge the is an appropriate rattling and rumbling of the ancient  timbers.

location: THE OPPOSITE SIDE OF THE BRIDGE

text: There is another fork in the road. Muriel points to the r to the right. Jim shakes his head, points to the road to left. Muriel points to the right. Jim emphatically shakes his head, puts the car in gear, drives off on the road to the left.
LONG SHOT - the car. It goes up to the top of a hill, sto starts up, disappears.
As the car approaches, the CAMERA discloses it is back at the same covered bridge. The car stops.
Jim reacts with annoyance, mops his brow.
(drily) Congress ought to pass a law. When a  man buys a house in Lansdale County  there's a prize -- he gets ten percent  off if he can find it.
Jim backs up and, over Muriel's protestation that they go right, turns the car left.
LONG SHOT - the car. It drives up an empty road, disappea
As the car approaches, the CAMERA reveals it is again bac at the old covered bridge. The sign still reads: "SHRUNK  MILLS - 2 Mi."
Jim and Muriel look at each other with disgust and  resignation.
What in the world are "Shrunk Mills?"
They are probably mills that have  shrunk.
Well, you certainly aren't much of a  help.
(wearily) Look -- you really want to find that  house of yours -- it's no problem.
They look at him curiously.
Just pretend you're one of General  Gates' horses and you're thirsty...  Now where would you go for a drink  of water?
Jim looks at him darkly, drives through the bridge, turns right, as Muriel looks slightly triumphant.
Jim, Muriel and Bill stand a little distance from the hou looking at it. A vast lilac spreads across it. The Blandi are in quiet rapture, and it is Bill who speaks first.
(frank and open) Well, I must admit it's a very  beautiful thing.
(misty) The house and the lilac are just the  same age, Bill; if the lilac can  live and be so old, so can the house.  It just needs someone to love it,  that's all.
Three shingles slide from the roof. As Jim and Muriel rea
It's a good thing there are two of  you -- one to love it and one to  hold it up.
As Jim gives him a look:
What'd your engineer say when he  checked over the foundation and that  roof?
Who needs engineers? This isn't a  train, you know.
I just saw it move.
This house has been standing since  the second year of the Continental  Congress. You take one look at it  and shingles start to fall off!
As if on cue, a few more shingles slide off the roof, nea hitting Jim.
(solicitously) Look -- let me do you a favor. I've  got a client, crackerjack structural  engineer, Joe Apollonio; he  practically built the George  Washington Bridge single-handed.
Thanks a lot, but we're not building  a bridge.
He's the follow who advised the  Government not to raise the Normandie --  they didn't listen to him, cost them  five million dollars.
You have my word, if I were raising  the Normandie, I wouldn't make a  move without Apollonio. (indicates door) Now would you like to come inside  and look around?
(a skeptical look at  the roof) No thanks, I'll just stay out in the  car and listen to "Life Can Be  Beautiful."
As Jim opens the door and disappears, there is a crash,  followed by a series of other crashes. Muriel looks in, t back to Bill.
I think you'd better contact Mr.  Apollonio.

Near the front entrance. After a moment, the door opens, the Blandings and Mr. Apollonio emerge. Jim, limping, is  aided and abetted by a cane. Apollonio is a stolid, New Y construction man, replete with derby, blue serge suit, an cigar. A short rule sticks out of a back pocket. As they  emerge, the Blandings are hopefully enthusiastic; Apollon is thoughtfully noncommittal.
It has charm, hasn't it, Mr.  Apollonio?
(through his cigar) Uh-huh.
Of course, any small changes would  have to conform with the character  of the countryside.
(through his cigar) Mm-hmm.
And yet still be functional.
Apollonio casually walks over to the corner of the house, kicks an exposed beam. It crumbles, apparently rotted by  termites. Two shingles fall off. The Blandings watch him  anxiously.
(gazing upward;  oblivious) Uh-huh.
As he thoughtfully rubs his chin, Jim, followed by Muriel limps his way over to him.
Well, uh, what's your professional  opinion?
Apollonio looks at the Blandings, at the house, then back the Blandings. He takes the cigar from his mouth.
Tear it down.
(appalled) Tear it down??!

If your chimney was shot and your  sills was okay, I'd say go ahead,  fix her up. If your sills was shot  and your chimney was okay, again I'd  say go ahead, fix her up. But your  sills are shot and your chimney is  shot.
During this speech Apollonio picks up a wooden frame, squ it with a pocket square, levels it on a fence, and looks  through it at the house.
(beckoning) Take a look at the way she sags.
The Blandings step over, look through the frame. WHAT THEY SEE. What they see. Outlined against the frame, the house slan sagging perceptibly.
THREE SHOT as the Blandings react with some dismay.
So I say don't throw good money after  bad -- tear it down.
(coolly) Thanks a lot.
It's okay.
He tips his hat, walks out of scene.
(bitterly) Bill Cole and his experts!
(bitterly) Darling, we'll get our own experts.
The Blandings have just finished surveying the house with Mr. Simpson, another expert.
And so they got their own experts.  Mr. Simpson said --
Tear it down.
The Blandings look at each other.
The Blandings have just finished examining the house with Mr. Murphy, another expert.
On the other hand, Mr. Murphy said --
I think you'd better tear it down.
The Blandings smile feebly.
The Blandings and Jones, another expert.
And then just to be a wee bit  different, Mr. Jones said --
(firmly; deep bass  voiced) Tear it down!
The Blandings are now considerably shaken.
A shingle. It reads in neat, conservative lettering:
And that's how our friend, Mr. Simms,  came into it.

Jim, Muriel, Simms. The room is in quiet, good taste, a  flagstone fireplace, modern steel casement windows, windo seats, etc. The walls are crammed with books and photogra of Simms' handiwork. There are a couple of gold medal  citations of his work conspicuously spaced around the roo Simms is a tweedy, pipe-smoking, conservative New England a distinguished-looking local architect. He puffs thought on his pipe as he looks at a photograph of the old Hacket place, an exact duplicate of the shot we saw through the  window frame.

Of course you could fix up that old  house. You can fix up any structure  that's still standing. The sills and  floors couldn't be worse, I grant  you, and I guess you'd have to jack  up that west corner at least three  feet to make it level. Need new  chimney. New roof. Complete new  plumbing. (sigh) Too bad you didn't buy it ten years  ago. Could have fixed it up in jig  time then, and it would have made  some sense.
(nervously nibbling  at his nails) Uh-huh... mm-hmmm... uh-huh.
Fact is, before you're through, it  would be less expensive to tear the  old place down and build a new one,  same size.
Mm. New house... (as the notion sinks  in, becomes attractive) New house.
(to Simms, with  pleasant incredulity) You mean... for the same money... we  could build a brand new house?
It certainly wouldn't cost any more.
(soberly) Hm... New house...
He turns and looks thoughtfully at Muriel who raises an  interested eyebrow. Then, to Simms:
(tentatively) Just... what sort of thing do you  have in mind?

Well, I imagine the type of house  you'd want would be something in  quiet good taste, two story, frame  and brick veneer construction --  modern, but of course fitting in  with the architectural traditions of  the countryside.
Well, I -- What do you think, Muriel?
I think it sounds fine.
Perhaps you'd like to see a basic  floor plan -- (reaches into file  behind him) -- something like this.

Simms places the basic floor plan on the desk before him, the Blandings moving around, flanking him. They examine t plan with interest. WHAT THEY SEE -- THE PLAN. What they see -- the plan. A simple master plan of a two  story house, the names of the various rooms indicated. As talks, we see Simms' hand, holding a pencil, point out th various rooms
First floor. Living room, study,  dining room, kitchen, service porch,  maid's room -- upstairs three family  bedrooms with two adjoining baths.
THREE SHOT. The Blandings praise the plan with the  uncompromising expertness of two people who have never se such a plan before in their lives.
It's very nice, I'm sure, but -- uh --  well -- doesn't it seem just a little  bit conventional?
Yes, Simms, if we were going to build  a house we want it -- well, you know --  just a little bit different.
(he's heard all this  before) Yes, of course.
Now, for instance -- (takes Simms' pencil)
THE DRAWING BOARD. Jim's pencil traces as he talks.
-- here in the study if we could  just push out this wall a little --  and put in a built-in bar we could --
Excuse me, dear --
Her hand takes the pencil from his, starts to trace as sh talks. Jim's fingers drum with the beginnings of impatien
These bedrooms. They do seem rather  small. And, of course we'd have to  have a little dressing room -- and --
As she draws it in, Jim's hand takes the pencil. Muriel's fingers drum nervously.
And closets, Simms, lots of closets. (traces them in) If there's one thing this family  needs, it's closets.
(as his hand reaches  for the pencil) If I might make a suggestion --
But Muriel's hand reaches the pencil first.
(as she draws them in) And bathrooms, Mr. Simms. Each bedroom  must have at least one bathroom.
But that would be four bathrooms,  Mrs. Blandings -- (his hand reaches for  the pencil) I think I'd better point out to you --
Jim's hand reaches the pencil before Simms. Now Simms' fi and Muriel's drum in unison.
Just a minute. Do you think -- (tracing) we might manage a little playroom in  the basement, nothing tremendous,  you know, something like this --
(as his hand reaches  for the pencil;  cautiously) Well, it's always possible, but at  the moment our fundamental problem --
But Muriel's hand has the pencil.

(as she traces) And I've always wanted a little sewing  room upstairs -- (Jim's and Simms'  fingers drum  impatiently) You know, a little utility room where  I can be alone, and sew, or sulk, or  on a rainy afternoon...
(as his hand takes  pencil) Pardon me, dear. On that playroom,  Simms, not too small. You know, plenty  of room for ping-pong, darts, nice  big poker table...
(as his hand reaches  for another pencil) If you don't mind, I --
But Muriel has reached the pencil first. As she and Jim s simultaneously and the scene begins to DISSOLVE, we hear:
...And off the kitchen, I'd like a  little flower sink just to putter  around in...
...And a terrace off the study, with  an owning and little outdoor  fireplace...
THE DRAWING BOARD - The original plans are lost in a maze the Blandings' extensions, alterations and additions.
THREE SHOT - The three are somewhat exhausted, silently  looking at the plans. Simms wearily runs his hand through his hair.
(delicately) We-ll... let's just see what we have  here. In the first place --
THE DRAWING BOARD - Simms' pencil indicates as he talks.
-- I'm afraid you've got the upstairs  about twice as big as the downstairs.
It's all those bathrooms.
It is not, it's all those closets.
By extending this breakfast room  you've eliminated the possibility of  any stairs going to the second floor.
Oh, you can just shove those stairs  in anywhere.

(patiently; almost  paternally) And, Mrs. Blandings, on that sewing  room, the way you have it now, the  chimney stack would come up right  through the middle of the room,  leaving you with something in the  shape of a square doughnut. (tactfully) Which, of course, might be very warm  in winter, but otherwise of doubtful  utility.
You could always move the chimney  somewhere else, couldn't you?
We-ll... (rising; resigned to  his fate but tactful) Look, I think I know just about what  you two have in mind. Why don't I go  ahead with some preliminary plans  and --
(hearty) You do that, Simms, but remember,  we've got to hold it down to ten  thousand.
(candid) That, I can tell you right now, is  impossible. Even with a considerable  trimming of the things you've  indicated, I don't see how we can  bring it in for less than twelve or  twelve-five.
Twelve-five! (looks at Muriel;  then) Well, I guess we're not going to  quibble about a few pennies one way  or the other.
(can't resist) No, you'll find Mr. Blandings never  quibbles about pennies.
And -- uh -- have you any notions  about how you'd like the old place  taken down?
(a rueful joke) Why don't we just blow on it?
(wry smile) There's a good local house wrecker.  I'll have him contact you.
Jim expansively puts his arm around Simms' shoulders.
Fine. You just shoot ahead with those  plans, and remember, try to keep it  down to ten, ten-five.
(doubtfully) Well -- we'll try.
As the Blandings walk to the door:
There's one good thing about getting  that old relic down. Those original  beams and everything -- this time  somebody pays us.
As they go out the door:

Old Hackett house matted to show winter sky, bare trees. the f.g. bare ground with patches of snow. Eph Hackett is standing with one of the wreckers. In the  b.g. we see the frame of the old house, firmly intact, th chimney still standing within it. There are mountains of  shingles, splintered boards and other rubbish, piled abou The piles are reasonably neat and sorted.
Them beams is worth money. You payin'  him, or he payin' you?
He's payin' me.
How much?
(hesitating) A thousand.
A thousand!
He squawked, but he paid.
(drily) Hmm. I guess maybe I got a little  somethin' comin' too.
As he starts out of scene:
Okay, boys, let her go!
Tractors attached to chains and cables start to pull.
MINIATURE SHOT - What is left of the house collapses.

head_text.subj: EXT. HILL OVERLOOKING THE OLD HACKETT PLACE

text: Jim and Muriel are standing there, having watched the  demolition. As the dust settles:
(sigh) Well, so far it's cost us thirteen  thousand, three hundred and twenty- nine dollars and forty-five cents.
But we've got the nicest vacant lot  in the state of Connecticut.
They exchange a look of mixed emotions.
INSERT SIMMS' NEW PRELIMINARY PLANS - Fresh and workmanli a few small sections crossed out where cuts have been  indicated.
(wearily) Something will have to give somewhere,  that I know.
The CAMERA ANGLE WIDENS to disclose:
Jim, Muriel and Simms are going over the preliminary plan Betsy and Joan are present, Betsy reading the Lansdale Bl and Joan reading a science book.
It's impossible. I don't see how we  can cut another inch.
Honey, you heard Simms. As the house  stands now it's over fifteen thousand  dollars!
Well, it just doesn't seem possible -- (afterthought) for a house with such small rooms.
(patiently) Mrs. Blandings, I've already  explained. It's not only the size of  the rooms so much as it is the number.  You see, our primary problem is one  of cubage --
That's right, dear, cubage.
What's that?
Oh -- (sorry he got into it) just a figure of speech.
But what does it mean?
(a little irritably) Cubage. It's just the number of cubic  feet that -- (lost, lamely) -- go into a cubic foot. Go on, Simms.
(consulting plans) Now is it absolutely essential for  each of your daughters to have her  own room with two closets and a  separate bath?
(a look at the girls;  clearing his throat) Yes. You see, er, my daughters are,  er, approaching womanhood, and, er --
(brief look at the  girls) I hadn't realized they were  approaching it quite so fast. (to Jim) Perhaps what you need is not so much  a house as a series of little  bungalows.
Hmmm. (examining plans) What about that silly flower sink?  We could eliminate that.
I beg your pardon.
Or that sewing room upstairs, that's  certainly a waste.
If we're going to eliminate anything,  we'll lose that ridiculous play room  in the basement with that great big  poker table.
Honey, I've got to have some  relaxation.
We've got thirty-one and a half acres.  Go out in the back and do a little  gardening.
Sure, and get poison ivy!
(with dogged patience) If I may interrupt, I'd like to  suggest that none of these are really  major eliminations. Now if we could  do with one less bathroom on the  second floor --
I'm sorry. We couldn't possibly.
Mrs. Blandings, a simple bathroom,  eight by ten by eight with grade A  fixtures will cost around thirteen  hundred dollars.
I refuse to endanger the health of  my children in a house with less  than four bathrooms.
For thirteen hundred dollars they  can live in a house with three  bathrooms and rough it!
Look, perhaps the most practical  thing would be --
Oh, look, we're in the Lansdale paper! (reading) "Historical Society Blasts Vandalism!"
Muriel, Simms explained to you. We've  just got to cut, cut -- (reacts) What's that?
(reading) "Censure Vote Passed re Destruction  of Famed Hackett Edifice."
Well, isn't that just too bad! Let  me see that.
He takes the paper, scans it, suddenly bursts into laught
What's so funny.

(laughing) Prutty. Mrs. Bildad Prutty. Get a  load of this! (reads) "The semi-monthly meeting of the  Lansdale Historical Society was turned  into an uproar last night when its  president, Mrs. Bildad Prutty" --  How do you like that, Bildad Prutty? --  "reported the total demolition by  its New York buyer of the historic  old Hackett house." (laughs) Bildad Prutty! Muriel, I've got to  send this to the New Yorker!
(drily) Read on, father.

(scans paper) "Mrs. Prutty," -- Bildad, that is --  "reminded her audience that several  years ago the Society started to  raise a fund to purchase and restore  the old house to its original  condition." (looks up, laughs  scornfully)
Read on, father.

(back to paper) "The project fell through by being  seven hundred dollars short of the  sum of twenty-six hundred dollars..." (Jim slows down as  the following  registers) "...which Ephemus Hackett testified  was the lowest reasonable price he  could accept as --"
The paper drops.
(weakly) ...Twenty-six hundred dollars.
And what did we pay, father?
Eleven-five, with the commission.
Muriel, isn't it time for those  children to be in bed?
Now girls, I don't want to tell you  again.
The front doorbell rings.
Excuse me.
As the CAMERA FOLLOWS Muriel to the door, we hear:
Twenty-six hundred dollars!
(comfortingly) I wouldn't be too concerned about  Mrs. Prutty and her committee. After  all, it's your property and if you  want to tear it down --
Muriel opens the door, admits an excited Bill Cole.
(surprised) Why, Bill!

(briefly) Hello, Muriel. (he strides past her  waving a telegram;  to Jim) Well, you've done it again'. Once,  just once, why don't you come to me  and find out if it's all right, if  it's legal, before you go barging  off and run yourself smack into  another jam!
What's eating you?
(ignoring him; to  Simms) And I must say, Simms, I hold you  equally responsible!
(alarmed) What? What happened?
I'm afraid I don't understand.
(to Simms; indicating  Jim) Did you let this idiot tear down  that house?
What if he did? What of it?
(to Bill) Reconstruction was unsound and totally  impractical.
I quite agree. But you're dealing  with a man who doesn't think before  he acts, who goes off half-cocked!
What is it? What did I do?
(ignoring him; to  Simms) You're an architect! You must have  been aware of the legality involved.
What? What legality?
(to Simms) You knew there was a mortgage on  that house.
I assumed as much.
What happened? What are you talking  about?
(ignoring him; to  Simms) And you know the requirements in  regard to a mortgage where there's  demolition intended!
Certainly. But since you were his  lawyer, I naturally assumed --
With a man like this you can't assume  anything!
(loudly) Just one minute! I am entitled to  know what I did! This is America! A  man's guilty until he's proven  innocent --
It's the other way around, father.
You go to bed!
Girls!
Bill, I've had a very trying day.  Would you mind telling me in clear,  concise English just what crime I've  committed -- and why?!
(with weary resignation) In clear, concise English, you tore  down a house on which another man  holds a mortgage without first getting  his written permission.
Well, I -- I did?!
And in such case, the mortgagee can  demand the full payment of said  mortgage upon demand -- (waves telegram) and Mr. Ephemus Hackett so demands!  Six thousand clams! And he wants  them now!
(appalled) Now?!
You've got ten days.
Jim gulps. Pause.
For six thousand dollars we could  have had a Solaxion house and a Crane  Mobile home.
Muriel!
(herding the kids  toward the door) Girls, say your good nights and off  to bed without another word.
(reluctantly) Good night, Mr. Simms. Uncle Bill.
(protesting) Miss Stellwagon says the problems of  the parents should be the problems  of the children.
(shooing them out) You keep that in mind, dear. It'll  help prepare you for motherhood.
The children exit. An embarrassed pause.
Perhaps we'd better let the plans go  for the time being and --
(weakly) No, Simms, I'll work this out. You  go ahead with your final plans and  let's see some estimates.
And we'll just forget about that  extra bathroom.
(preparing to leave) Very well. You'll hear from me as  soon as possible. Good night.
Good nights are exchanged. Muriel takes Simms out of scen toward the door. CAMERA HOLDS on Bill and Jim.
(defeated) Six thousand dollars!
Bill looks at Jim with compassion.
What'll you do for collateral on  your building loan?
I don't know, turn in my insurance  policies or something.
(coming into scene) Now, Jim, you can't do that.
Why not?
What if something should happen? You  can't leave the children unprotected.
(somewhat irritably) I'm not dead yet! And if I die,  there's plenty left to take care of  them.
Not if you cash in your policies.
As Jim reacts with painful resignation:
I'm sure it won't be necessary. I'll  see the boys at the bank. Maybe you  can put up your insurance as  collateral. If necessary, I'll sign  a personal note.
(wearily) Thanks, Bill.

(paternally) And Jim, do me a little favor. The  next time you're going to do anything,  or say anything, or buy anything,  think it over very carefully, and  when you're sure you're right --  forget the whole thing. Good night,  Muriel.
He goes to Muriel and kisses her on the cheek. Jim sees i is annoyed.
Good night, Bill.
CAMERA FOLLOWS Muriel and Bill to the door. He exits. Mur comes back into the room.
What a wonderful friend.
(darkly) What's with this kissing all of a  sudden?
What's that?
Just because a man is helpful in a  business way, it doesn't give him  extra-curricular privileges with my  wife!
That's a fine thing to say about a  friend of fifteen years!
(testy) Well, I don't like it. Every time he  goes out of this house, he shakes my  hand and he kisses you.
(sharply) Would you prefer it the other way  around?!
(irritably) Well, I don't like it, that's all!  Why is he always hanging around? Why  doesn't he ever get married -- or  something?
(assumed innocence) Because he can't find another girl  as sweet and pretty and wholesome as  I am.
Well -- it -- it doesn't look right.  There are limits to friendship and --
Muriel comes over, puts a sympathetic arm around him.
Darling, let's not be silly about  this. It's not Bill, it's the house  you're upset about.
(sigh) I suppose so.
They kiss.
Do you think it's worth all this?
Of course, darling. We're not just  building a house -- it's a home. A  home for ourselves -- and our children --  and maybe our children's children.
(whimsically) It's getting awfully crowded with  only three bathrooms.
They look at each other, smile and kiss intimately, as we
Jim and Muriel are watching Simms, who has just taken a  typewritten sheet from his files. Simms looks at the shee turns to them a little apprehensively.
Well -- here are the estimates. Before  you look at them, I think I'd better  explain --
Don't bother, Simms. (takes the sheet) I'm getting to be an old hand at  this sort of --
Jim is halfway into his chair as his eye catches the firs bid. There is a sharp MUSICAL EFFECT as Jim bounces out o his seat.
Jumping H. Mahogany --!!

The CAMERA GOES IN for a CLOSE SHOT of the column of  estimates. As the CAMERA IRISES DOWN ON each sum, there i dissonant MUSICAL EFFECT. Antonio Doloroso, Builders  $32,117.00 Caries & Plumline  $30,500.00 Julius Akimbo & Co.  $28,575.00 Zach, Tophet & Payne  $24,250.00 John Retch & Son  $21,000.00
THREE SHOT - Jim, Muriel, and Simms. Muriel has read the  column over Jim's shoulder.
Now obviously these bids are way out  of line, that is, all except John  Retch and Son at twenty-one thousand.
(reacting) Twenty-one thousand!
And with some judicious cutting, I  think we can pare that down to  eighteen.
We've only asked for the barest  necessities --
Frankly, with all the extras you two  have --
Never mind. (hands estimates to  Simms) If you'll just send us a bill for  your services, I'll see that it's  taken care of. (takes Muriel's hand  and starts for door) Now, if you'll excuse us.
Where are we going?
I am going out to get my head  examined! Then, if I don't jump off  the Brooklyn Bridge, I'm going to  find the owner of our building and  sign a twenty-year lease!
As they are about to exit, they pause as their eyes are c by a drawing on an adjacent drawing board.
What they see - a beautiful pencil and charcoal drawing o their completed prospective house. Under it, in neat lett is printed: RESIDENCE OF MR. AND MRS. JAMES H. BLANDINGS
Jim, Muriel, and Simms. They look at the drawing, then at each other. Jim's face softens. Muriel looks at him  appealingly.
(quietly) What's the name of that contractor?

INSERT JIM'S COST CHART. The house rests on the diagonal  line at the figure of $13,500. As the miniscule Jim and M watch with apprehension, the small figures of Smith and  Hackett are joined by Simms, John W. Retch, and several s contractors, who put their collective shoulders to the ho and push it past the Blandings and up to $31,000.00
A sign on a sawhorse - it reads:

Over scene is the thunderous dissonance of the various SO that go into preliminary construction. A steam shovel in  action, a bulldozer, the sawing of wood, and intermittent the loud, earth-shaking crash of a well-digger's rig. As the CAMERA PULLS BACK, we see the machines and workmen their various tasks. The scene has all the rustic peace o the invasion of Hollandia. The ANGLE CHANGES, and we see Jim, Muriel, and Bill drive the improvised driveway very close to the scene of activi
Jim and Muriel look at their property with unconcealed pr Bill is interested but would like it better if there were less noise.
(shouting over noise) Well, things are certainly humming.
(same) What's that?
(same) I said, humming.
Oh.
As they get out of the car, there is an unusually loud cr from the well-digger's rig.
(loud) What's going on over there?
(same) That's Mr. Tesander. He's digging  our well.
(same) Well? What happened to the trout  stream, with that pure, clear, cold  mountain water?
(same) I decided against it --
There is a sudden cessation of the steam shovel and compl silence. Jim, unaware of it, continues to shout.
The trout stream -- (reacts; quietly) didn't seem practical.
It wasn't exactly a decision, dear. (to Bill) We discovered the trout stream dries  up in August and the rest of the  year it's polluted.
(defensively; groping) Well, anyway, I'd rather have artesian  water. It's healthier. Calcium --  vitamins -- artesian --
(indicating) What's wrong with that steam shovel?
They look off.

head_text.subj: WHAT THEY SEE. A CLUSTER OF WORKMEN

text: WHAT THEY SEE. A cluster of workmen have gathered around Zucca, the driver of the steam shovel, who is swearing in voluble but undistinguishable Italian. JIM, MURIEL AND BILL. Jim, Muriel and Bill.
Better take a look.
He starts off for the steam shovel, nimbly jumping over a drainage trench. Muriel starts to follow, pauses, unable negotiate the trench.
Jim!
Jim turns in time to see Bill pick Muriel up and carry he across the trench. As he sets her down:
(sarcastic; to Jim) Thank you, dear.
Jim frowns, annoyed. They approach the group around the  shovel.
What's the matter, Mr. Zucca?  Something wrong?
How do you lika that? Broka my bucket.  Two times this week I broka my bucket?
What did you do, strike a boulder?
(darkly) Atsa no boulder, atsa ledge.
(weakly) What does that mean?
Meansa we gotta blast!
Blast?
Blast. Witha dynamite.
What do you mean, dynamite?
(a little annoyed) What do you mean, "What do you mean?"  Mr. Zucca just explained. He's going  to use dynamite and blast until he  gets rid of the rock.
Atsa no rock, atsa ledge.
What Mr. Blandings means is -- what  precisely is a ledge?
Ledge. Lika bigga stone, only a- bigger.
Like a boulder?
No, like ledge.
Jim looks at Muriel and Bill.
...Like a ledge.
But you don't gotta worry. Only cost  twenty-four cents a cubic foot, plussa  dynamite an'a fuse.
But how far will you have to blast?
Harda tell. Might be a lilla baby  ledge -- mighta run the whole toppa  the mountain.
(appalled) At twenty-four cents a foot? Do you  realize what that means?!
(simply) Meansa we gotta blast.
Zucca walks off.
(with quiet resignation) Well, anyway, our house will never  sink.
(drily) If it does, we can always get Mr.  Apollonio. He raised the Normandie.
There is a crash from the well-digging rig.
"Come to peaceful Connecticut -- (another crash) Trade city soot for sylvan charm."
Another crash.
(irritably) How long does that go on?
I don't know. (to Bill) Three weeks now at four dollars and  fifty cents a foot.
(asserting his  authority) I think I'd better have a little  talk with Mr. Tesander.
He starts off. Muriel and Bill, curious, follow.
Tesander, a stolid New England well-digger, the soul of  industry and candor, attacks the earth. Jim, followed by  Muriel and Bill, walks into scene, stands by, watching hi After a moment:
Oh -- Mr. Tesander --
The motor is making too much noise.
(louder) Mr. Tesander!
Tesander looks up, shuts off his motor.
Yep?
How's it coming?
(considers a moment;  then:) It's comin'.
With a nod he turns on his motor, resumes work. Jim excha a look with Muriel and Bill.
No -- no -- I mean --
But he's drowned out by the motor.
(shouts) Mr. Tesander!
Tesander patiently stops his motor, looks up.
Yep?
What I meant was -- how far down are  you?
Tesander looks at his equipment, considers.
Oh -- 'bout a hundred and ninety  feet.
Well -- isn't that pretty deep?
(thinks it over; he's  not one for snap  judgments; then:) Yep.
He's about to turn on his motor, but Jim detains him.
Do you think maybe you'd better try  another spot?
Up to you.
I mean -- well, have you hit anything  yet at all?
(thinks it over) Hit some limestone yesterday.
Is that good?
That's bad.
Jim looks at Bill who shakes his head with mock commisera
And right now it looks like we're  coming into some shale.
That's bad?
That's good.
Oh...
Jim looks at Muriel for comfort which isn't forthcoming.
'Course it might turn out to be  sandstone.
That's bad?
Tesander shakes his head, "No."
That's good?
Tesander shakes his head, "No."
Can't tell. Might be good. Might be  bad. One thing you know -- you got  plenty of shale, sandstone and  limestone.
...I see.
He turns a little helplessly to Muriel and Bill.
On a hot day there's nothing like a  nice cool limestone shower.
(sweetly) Mr. Tesander, just for the record,  of course, what ever happened to  water?
Oh, it's there, all right. (he smiles, nods,  tips his hat to Muriel) Just got to be patient.
