He turns on his motor, goes back to work. Jim, Muriel and Bill start to move off.
If you ask me, this project's getting  a little out of hand.

(defensively) Nothing's getting out of hand at  all. I've made a chart of the whole  operation, and -- (indicates Tesander) with a few minor deviations, I know  exactly what every penny's going to  cost.
Two pennies.
(coolly) And just what does that mean?
(drily) Meansa we gotta blast.
There is a loud dynamite blast o.s. As a shower of dirt a rocks cascade down and they run for cover:

INSERT JIM'S COST CHART - Jim stands casually above the h holding the line with one hand. The group pushing from be now consists of Smith, Hackett, Simms, Retch, Tesander, Z and assorted sub-contractors and workmen. As the house mo up a thousand dollars, Jim firmly pushes it back. It now  rests at $33,500.
Jim and Mary.

You see, Mary, the average fellow  who builds a house doesn't know where  he stands from day to day -- but I  do things a little differently. With  a few minor deviations I know exactly  where every penny is going --
There is a knock on the door. It opens and Bill Cole appe briefcase under his arm.
Hi.
Bill! Come in, come in.
(entering) Just going over the Knapp contracts  with old man Dascomb and I -- uh -- (indicates Mary) Can I talk?
(a little concerned) Sure. What's up?
(obliquely) While I was in there with Dascomb  the conversation kind of got around  to you and -- uh --
(impatiently) What is it?
Well, he didn't say in so many words  that ever since you started with  that house you haven't turned in a  decent piece of copy, but --
But you kind of got the feeling...
...that if I told you, you'd know  that he knew that you knew that he  knew... that you knew... or something.
What's he worrying about? The  deadline's three months off. I've  always --
The phone rings. Mary answers.
Hello? Yes. Just a minute. (hands phone to Jim) Mrs. Blandings calling from Lensdale.
Yes, Muriel. What? What's that?  Tesander struck water! Say that's  wonderful! (to Bill) We've finally got our well.
(drily) Congratulations.
He extends his hand. Jim absently shakes it, then:
(listens at phone) Huh? What's that? (face falls) What do you mean we've got two wells? (listens; then, grimly) I'll be right out. (hangs up, rises) Come on, Bill, we'd better get out  to Lansdale.
Anything wrong?
(soberly, as he slips  into his coat) Mary, have you ever seriously  considered building a house?
Well, no offense, Mr. Blandings, but  my boy friend says that anybody who  builds a house today is crazy.
You stick with that boy, he's got a  great future.
As he and Bill start for the door:
Muriel, Jim, Bill, Simms and Retch stand at the edge look down at the excavation which is partially filled with bub water.
You mean you hit a spring, a bubbling  spring right here in our cellar?
It'll have to be diverted before  Retch here can lay his cement.
(dubiously) May take a while. Pumps are over in  Jersey.
Tesander walks into scene, looks down at the water.
Tsk, tsk, tsk.
(mild sarcasm) Water, Mr. Tesander.
Yep.
At six feet!
Yep.
(indicates) And over there, just thirty-two yards  away, you had to go down two hundred  and twenty-seven feet to hit the  same water.
Yep.
How do you account for that, Mr.  Tesander?
Tesander considers a moment, rubs his chin, then:
We-ll, way it seems to me, Mr.  Blandings, over here the water's  down around six feet and over there  it's -- uh --
-- down around two hundred and twenty- seven feet.
Jim exchanges a weary look with Muriel.
SPECIAL EFFECT: It consists of a Montage of the following

(1) The water being pumped out of the excavation. (2) The cement mixer pouring cement into wheelbarrows. (3) The pouring of the cement floor, walls and foundation (4) Planks, shingles and plumbing equipment begin to arri and are strewn about the property. (5) The exterior framing of the house begins to go up. (6) The sheathing is put on. (7) The roof is constructed.

Jim's Cost Chart. - With each successive operation, a new workman is added to the already considerable group of peo who are pushing the house inexorably upward, this against the frantic efforts of a slowly weakening Jim Blandings.
The exterior sheathing is completed and, in the roughest terms, the project begins to resemble a house. Among the  workmen's cars we notice the Blandings' convertible.

A dozen hammers, saws, trowels, etc. are heard in other p of the house busily rasping and banging away. Jim and Mur and Bill appear in the doorway before entering the rough  unfinished interior of what will eventually be the living room.
What's this, another closet?
This happens to be our dining room.
Not the dining room, dear, the living  room. (indicates) There's the fireplace.
Then where's the dining room?
Maybe it's that little room off the  hallway.
That's the breakfast nook.
It's not the breakfast nook, it's  the powder room.
Oh.
Do me a favor -- don't ever invite  me here for a meal.
Two workmen pass by carrying a few long pieces of lumber. The workmen don't see the Blandings.
I don't figure this Blandings at  all. If you gotta build on the  windiest hill in Connecticut, why do  you have to pick the windiest side  of the hill?
(to workman) You know these New York millionaires --  they're eccentric.
The workmen pass from view.
I think I'd like to go outside.
(gesture to door) After you, Rockefeller.
As they enter the foyer, a carpenter appears.
(to Jim) Just the man I want to see. Would  you step over here a second?
Sure.
(indicating) I'll browse around upstairs.
As Bill starts up the stairs, Jim and Muriel follow the  carpenter.
(pointing up) On them second floor lintels between  the lally columns, do you want we  should rabbet them or not?
(lost) The -- second -- floor -- lallys?
The second floor lintels, between  the lallys.
Oh. Oh, the lintels between the  lallys?
Yeah. From the blueprints you can't  tell. You want they should be  rabbeted?
Jim throws a brief look at Muriel who is regarding him  skeptically.
Un -- umm. No, I guess not.
Okay, you're the doctor. (calls) Hey, fellas, you got any of them  rabbeted lintels set, rip 'em out!

After the sheerest pause there comes a shriek of nails  brutally withdrawn from timber, a loud splintering of woo and then something of the appearance of entrails comes  hurtling down end over end landing with a dusty slap at J feet. The carpenter exits. Muriel gives Jim an accusing l
(sheepishly) It sounded less... expensive to say  no.
There is another loud screech and more "entrails" come  hurtling down, narrowly missing them. Muriel yells in the direction from which they came.
Stop it! Stop it!
From upstairs comes a long, shrill whistle. Instantly all sound of activity ceases and a voice is heard.
Okay, fellas, let's quit!
(to Muriel) Now look what you've done.
As Muriel turns with apprehension, eighteen workmen come  trooping down the stairs.

(conciliatory) Look, men, Mrs. Blandings didn't  mean anything. (the workmen regard  him curiously) I mean, there's no point in walking  off a job just because... a woman  makes a silly little remark.
It's Saturday, mister. We quit at  twelve o'clock. This ain't a chain  gang, you know.
As the workmen exit the Blandings look at each other a li sheepishly, start up the stairs.

head_text.subj: AS THE BLANDINGS GO UP THE STAIRS

text: CRANE SHOT - as the Blandings go up the stairs.
I'm just sick. From the outside this  house looks like a grain elevator,  and on the inside everything's miles  too small.
As they reach the second floor landing, we hear, o.s. a s but muffled pounding. They stop as they hear the thumping.
What's that?
What's what?
That noise -- listen. (again the thumping) It's coming from the closet!
They rush to the closet, open the heavy oak door. Bill is inside, leaning disgustedly against the wall.
What happened?
The door blew shut. I got locked in.
Impossible. I had this closet built  especially for myself. The lock opens  from the inside.
Maybe for Houdini -- not for me.
As Bill starts to step out, Jim detains him.
Nothing to it. A child could work  it. Look, I'll show you.
He steps inside with Bill, firmly closes the door. A mome pause. The door re-opens.
(condescendingly) You see, it just takes a little good  old Yankee know-how.
You know, dear, it's just possible  the lock worked for you and not for  Bill.
Ridiculous. Even you could do it.
(sarcastic) Thank you.
Come on, I'll show you.
He ushers Muriel inside and the door closes on the threes The CAMERA REMAINS on the closed door.
Go ahead, dear, just open it.
The knob turns, jiggles a little, but the door remains cl
I don't seem to be able to ---
Here, let me show you! You just take  the knob and turn it clockwise.

An efficient clockwise turn of the knob. Pause. An impati doubletwist of the knob. Pause. A more forceful rattling the knob, plus a slight kick. A furious rattling, poundin and kicking. The door remains closed.
As Jim turns sheepishly:
Nothing like that good old Yankee  know-how.
Jim turns back to the door, pounds on it, yelling:
Hey! Hey! Somebody let us out of  here!
Silence. Muriel is at the shoulder-high circular frame so glass window. She looks out.
Oh, dear.
Jim and Bill look out.
WHAT THEY SEE - The last of the workmen's cars driving aw
(drily) Leave a call for seven o'clock. (afterthought) Monday morning.
Jim gives him a look, turns back to the window, sizing up escape, starts muttering to himself.
If I could just get over to that  scaffolding...
He tests the window frame, finds it solid.
(still muttering) Seems a shame but I guess it's the  only way...
Jim picks up a piece of tar paper.
What are you going to do?
Don't get panicky, I'll get you out  of here. (hands tar paper to  Bill) Here, hold this over the window.
As Bill somewhat skeptically complies, Jim picks up a pie of two-by-four.
Stand back, Muriel.
Jim raises the plank, takes a stance.
(to Bill) Ready?
Roger.

Jim swings; the window shatters. Almost simultaneously th is a click and the door to the closet swings open. As Jim turns with a sense of accomplishment, his face falls as h and the others see that the erratic door has opened.
(sweetly) In case of emergency -- break glass.  Come on, Bill.
As Muriel and Bill precede Jim out of the closet and down the stairs, Jim pauses, speculatively toying with the loc
(muttering) Funny... always worked before. Huh.  I wonder...
Muriel and Bill walking down the stairs. From upstairs co a steady sullen pounding from the interior of the closet. Without a word, they stop, look at each other, turn and w back upstairs.
Muriel and the children are having breakfast. Jim enters, fairly high spirits, once again improvising to "Home On T Range."
(as he sits down) "Home, home in Connecticut -- Where  you have to conform to local  traditions, customs, politics and  etiquette..." (picks up his morning  mail, starts to thumb  through it)
Dad, do you suppose I could have a  chemistry lab in the basement?
(preoccupied with  mail) Sure, why not?
I think it's awful. Smelling up the  house with those horrible chemicals.
Never mind, Betsy. (to Jim) Dear, I'm going up to the place this  afternoon to see about landscaping.  Bill's driving me.
(preoccupied) That's nice. (looking up; darkly) What do you mean, Bill's driving  you?
(a little annoyed) Why do you always say, "what do you  mean," when you know perfectly well  what I mean and what you mean?
I mean that every time I turn my  back Bill Cole's driving you some  place or something.
He's only being helpful.
(annoyed; tears open  a letter) I thought he was a lawyer! Why isn't  he out suing somebody?
Bicker, bicker, bicker.
(to Joan) Another word and you don't get your  laboratory.
Well, that's something!
Jim suddenly explodes, crumpling a letter he has just rea
We'll just see about that!
(concerned) What is it, dear?
Ignoring her, he reaches for the phone, starts to dial.
Jim, what's the matter?

(into phone; sharply) Mr. William Cole, please. (pause; then with  rising emotion) Hello, Bill? I want you to fight  this thing! I know my rights as a  citizen! They can't get away with  it!... What do you mean, what am I  talking about? The letter, of course.  From the owner of this building.  They want us to move! It's a thirty  day notice! (listens a moment) But that's ridiculous. How can I  move into a house that isn't even  finished?! No windows, no plaster --  or paint, or -- or plumbing! (listens a moment;  then with rising  emotion) Now you listen to me! I have no  intention of moving in thirty days!  This is not legal! I'm going to fight  this thing! And I don't care if it  takes every penny I've got! (listens) Yeah... Yeah... Yeah... All right! (hangs up)
(expectantly) ...Well?
(quietly) We're moving in thirty days.
On Muriel's reaction:
Two moving vans are approaching the bridge. Behind them i the Blandings' convertible. In it are Jim, Muriel and the children. Behind it and attached is a trailer. After a pa over this, we hear:
So-came thirty days -- and they moved.
MED. CLOSE SHOT - Entrance to bridge. As the cavalcade pa through we see in the rear of the trailer, jammed among t household effects, Gussie and a very uncomfortable Mr. Bi Cole.
I mean -- we moved.

head_text.subj: OTHER END OF BRIDGE AND FORK

text: The moving vans precede the convertible, make the wrong t Jim stops the convertible at the fork and honks as he  impatiently gestures to the drivers to turn in the opposi direction. Over this:
(as Jim would say it) That's the wrong road! Any fool knows  that!
Jim starts his car up leading the way.
The moving vans turn up the new gravel driveway. Jim stop his car and they all look off at the house, react with  pleasant surprise.

WHAT THEY SEE - LONG SHOT - The house is rapidly nearing  completion. A half dozen men are finishing the exterior  painting, planing down doors, etc. In front, a couple of from the nursery are working on the landscaping. For the  first time we, as well as the Blandings, see the property a clean, bright and very attractive new house.
Well, there she is, bright and shining --  and just about complete -- the  residence of Mr. and Mrs. James H.  Blandings.
MOVING SHOT - Jim and Muriel are visibly affected by the  sight of their Dream House. They exchange a warm intimate smile.
Not bad at that.
MED. SHOT. The car pulls up, stops.
(efficient scoutmaster) All right! -- Everybody out.
Everybody piles out of the car. As Jim and Muriel walk to the house away from us and Bill, Muriel sentimentally rea out, takes Jim's hand.
Guess you can't blame them for feeling  just a little bit proud.
At the door, Jim stops, indicates that he'd like to carry Muriel across the threshold.
(sentimentally) Look -- he wants to carry his wife  across the threshold. Romantic, isn't  it?
Joan and Betsy. They look on with distinct adolescent  disapproval.
Ooops! I guess I meant "corny."
GROUP SHOT. Over Muriel's playful protest, Jim starts to  pick her up.
Uh-uh. Watch that sacroiliac. Fifteen  years since you've done this sort of  thing.
Jim manages to lift Muriel.
Whew! Nice work, Tarzan. Now, let's  see if you can make it into the hall.
Jim carries Muriel over the threshold and into the foyer.
That's right. Go right in. Don't pay  any attention to the sign.
The CAMERA PANS TO a LOW SHOT of a sign on the floor of t foyer. It reads:

FULL SHOT - foyer. In the b.g. is a painter, varnishing t floor. He looks up in complete dismay as he sees his newl varnished floor being violated. After a couple of steps, stops, suddenly aware of the painter. The painter rises,  throws down his brush, says something caustic.
(imitating painter) Don't mind me, buddy, I just got  through varnishing that floor.
Jim reacts, raises a tentative foot, the sticky varnish  practically holding it to the floor. Jim says something.
Whose bright idea was this?
The painter says something, points at Muriel. Jim looks d and accusingly at Muriel whose weak smile is an admission guilt.
She just wanted everything to be  nice and shiny on the day they moved  in.
Jim turns and shouts something to the painter.
Stop painting that floor and put  some planks down in here, or some  thing!
The painter shouts back.
Okay, mister, but take it easy. The  Republicans ain't in yet, you know.
Jim reacts, turns and walks back out of the foyer, desper trying to match his clearly outlined incoming footsteps.  Each step is outlined by strands of thick sticky varnish.

location: THE FRONT DOOR OF THE HOUSE

text: As Jim appears, still carrying Muriel, Betsy and Joan cat his attention, indicate the front wall of the house which complete except for the windows. Jim reacts.
Oh, fine! A house without windows!  We'll just see about that!
Abruptly handing Muriel to Bill he starts off. Ahead of h and unnoticed are a layer of newspapers which have been s out.
Look out for those papers!

But Jim has stepped on the papers. They stick to his feet After a few steps he is aware of it, tries to get rid of  them. After a few hectic but futile attempts, he disguste disappears around a corner of the house, the newspapers  flapping behind him.
Jim flaps his way up to a workman who is staring at a pil of window casements.
Where's Simms?
Around back trying to figure out  what to do about them windows.
What's the problem? You put windows  up.
Not these. They don't fit.
(angrily; control  going) Oh, they don't, don't they?
He continues on toward the back of the house, the newspap flapping beneath him.

Simms and Retch. More window frames are neatly stacked ag the wall. Simms and Retch react as they see an angry Jim  Blandings flap his way into scene, his varnished shoes ha picked up additional paper, shavings, shingles, etc. Retc hands Jim a sheaf of papers.
Oh, Mr. Blandings, you'd better look  these over.
What's this about the windows?
(calmly) I'm afraid there's a little slip-up.  These windows seem to belong to a  Mr. Landings in Fishkill, New York.  I talked to Mr. Landings this morning.
Well, has he got mine?
No, he seems to have some windows  that belong to a Mr. Blandsworth of  Peekskill.
Where are my windows?!
As near as we can figure out they've  either been sent to a Mr. Benton in  Evanston, Illinois, or a Mr. Bamberger  of Phoenix, Arizona.
Bill wanders into scene, looks over Jim's shoulder.
What are we supposed to do -- live  the rest of our lives in a house  without windows?
It'll just be a matter of a few days.
What's a "Zuz-Zuz Water Soft-N-R"?
How should I know?
(indicating) You've got one.
(reading from bill) "Furnishing and installing one Zuz- Zuz Water Soft-N-R, two hundred and  eighty dollars!" (explosively) I will not have any such piece of  equipment in my house!
I'm afraid I authorized that, Mr.  Blandings -- to save your boiler and  water pipes.
From what?!
Rust. The plumbing man assures us  the water from your well is the most  corrosive in his entire experience  in the trade.
Another first!
(pursing his lips) Mm. (irritably) Well, if it's necessary, put it in!  We're moving in today, you know and --
It's in.
Oh. (a final show of  authority; sharply) Then get me the bill for it!
(indicating bill) You've got it.
All right then.
And he stalks off, his papers, shavings, etc. flapping be him.
The moving vans are driving away.

A general flurry of activity; Gussie and several workmen  carrying furniture upstairs, unpacking barrels, etc. Muri list and samples in hand, is explaining her color scheme Mr. PeDelford, a polite, cigar-smoking, noncommittal boss painter. In the b.g., casually leaning on the bannister i PeDelford's taciturn and somewhat skeptical-looking assis
Now I want the living room to be a  soft green. (PeDelford nods) Not quite as bluish as a robin's  egg, but yet not as yellow as daffodil  buds.
Mm.

(handing him a sample) The best sample I could get is a  little too yellow, but don't let  whoever mixes it go to the other  extreme and get it too blue. It should  just be sort of a grayish yellow  green.
(making a note) Mm-hmm.
They turn to the dining room.
Now the dining room I'd like yellow.  Not just yellow, a very gay yellow.
Mm-hmm.

Something bright and sunshiny. (sudden inspiration) I tell you, Mr. PeDelford, if you'll  just send one of your workmen to the  A&P for a pound of their best butter  and match it exactly, you can't go  wrong.
(making a note) Mm.

This is the paper we're going to use  here in the foyer. (hands sample to him) It's flowered but I don't want the  ceiling to match any of the colors  of the flowers. There are some little  dots in the background, and it's  these dots I want you to match. Not  the little greenish dots near the  hollyhock leaf, but the little bluish  dot between the rosebud and the  delphinium blossom. Is that clear?
PeDelford looks carefully at the sample, then:
(making note) Mm-hmm.
The kitchen's to be white. Not a  cold, antiseptic hospital white -- a  little warmer but not to suggest any  other color but white.
(note) Mm.
Now for the powder room, I want you  to match this thread. (hands him thread) You can see it's practically an apple  red. Somewhere between a healthy  Winesap and an unripened Jonathan.
(making note) Mm.
There is a crash from the kitchen.
Will you excuse me?
Muriel hastily exits toward the kitchen. PeDelford turns his assistant.
Got it, Charlie?
(deadpan; indicating  rooms with his thumb) Green, yellow, blue, white, red.
Check.
Joan is on a stepladder helping Gussie put away some dish Remains of two broken plates are on the floor below them.
Joan, you know father was to take  care of the heavy dishes.
He disappeared. I haven't seen him  for an hour.
Betsy flies into the room waving a railroad timetable.
Where's Uncle Bill? I just checked  the timetable -- he's going to miss  his train.
If they've run off somewhere it  certainly isn't very -- (suddenly stops,  listens)
From upstairs comes the SOUND of a steady, methodical thu of a hand on a solid oak door.
Heavens!
She rushes for the door.

Muriel opens the closet door revealing Jim and Bill, who  have been locked in the closet for the last hour. Each le against the wall, arms folded, in an attitude of boredom disgust. Without a word Jim and Bill exit from the closet The three start down the stairs.
(darkly) I thought you were going to take  care of it.
I thought you were.
(from below) You're going to miss your train,  Uncle Bill! It leaves Lansdale in  twenty-five minutes.
Isn't there a later one?
Not till the Commuter's Special  tomorrow morning at six-fifteen.
You mean seven-fifteen.
No, Dad, six-fifteen.
What about the seven-fifteen I'm  supposed to take to the office every  morning?!
(consulting timetable) There's a little asterisk. The seven- fifteen only runs Saturdays, Sundays  and holidays.
(taking timetable) Let me see that! (scans table,  tightlipped) Muriel!
Oh, dear, don't tell me I read it  wrong.

That's fine! For the rest of my life  I'm going to have to get up at five  o'clock in the morning to catch the  six-fifteen, to get to my office by  eight, which doesn't even open until  nine -- and which I never get to  until ten!
Perhaps if you started earlier you  could quit earlier.
(sharply) So I could get home earlier to go to  bed earlier to get up earlier!
Maybe you can have the railroad push  the train up to four-fifteen -- then  you won't have to go to bed at all!
Uncle Bill, you're going to miss  your train!
Jim, you clean up this mess. I'll  drive Bill to the station and pick  up some cold cuts for dinner.
Betsy and Joan pick up some boxes and walk into the dinin room.
You'd better hurry!
(indicating upstairs  closet) Kind of hate to leave that little  place. Just four walls and a couple  of mothballs, but to me it'll always  be home.
(preoccupied with  timetable) So long, Bill.
Bill and Muriel exit.
As Jim drifts in, still preoccupied with timetable:
It's certainly going to be fun this  summer when Uncle Bill comes up for  his vacation.
We'll get in a lot of doubles.
Hmm? (looks up from  timetable) What are you talking about? Bill's  going to Europe.
No, he's not. I heard him and mother  talking. He's going to move his  vacation up and take a place in  Lansdale.
(vaguely annoyed) Uh-huh... Mm-hm. Mm-hm... Uh-huh. (then, covering up) All right, come on, come on. Get  busy.
Evening is beginning to fall as Muriel drives Bill into t
I'll scout around and find you a  place in Lansdale. (quickly) Now, you're not going to change your  mind about coming up?
Don't worry, I'll be on the job.
It won't be easy. I promise you a  Cook's tour of every lamp maker, rug  weaver, and antique shop in Lansdale  County.
(philosophically) When I married you two I suppose I  took you for better or for worse.
Muriel smiles warmly, and in a friendly gesture reaches o and pats his hand.
Good old Uncle Bill.
(drily) Good old Uncle Bill.
As they exchange an understanding smile:

It is dark outside and getting quite chilly. The children are unpacking a last barrel. They have made a rather unst pile of books and boxes, obviously Muriel's personal effe Jim is in the process of trying to start his first fire i the fireplace. The immediate result is a clouding of the  room with smoke. As he backs away, coughing, he bumps int the pile which falls to the floor spilling open a box whi contains, among other things, Muriel's diary and a lifeti accumulation of sentimental trinkets.
Now look what you've done!
Betsy coughs her way to the fireplace, turns the flue han The smoke immediately goes up the chimney and the room st to clear.
Father, the first principle of  lighting a fire is to see if the  flue is open. A three-year-old child  knows that.
Next time we want a fire I'll send  out for a three-year-old child! (indicates trinkets) Get that stuff cleaned up and go in  and help Gussie set the table. It's  getting late.
The children start gathering up the debris. Joan picks up some trinkets which have spilled from a cardboard box.
Look, Dad, your fraternity pins.
(busy cleaning the  fireplace) Pins? I only had one.
There are two of them here.
All right, all right. Just put them  away.
(examining them) Funny, this one says W.C. on the  back. W.C.? (brightly) William Cole! It must be Uncle Bill's!
Huh? (reaching for it) Let me see that. (examining pin) Hmmmm.
Betsy has picked up a small leather-bound book. She whist
What's that?
Mother's diary when she was in  college. It's slightly torrid.
(coming over) Let's see.
(sharply) That's none of your business!
(scanning page) I'd say mother and Uncle Bill were  somewhat of an item!
(taking book from  Betsy) People do not read other people's  diaries! It's not a very nice thing  to do! (shooting them out) Now go in there and help Gussie with  the table.
(indicating debris) What about --?
I'll take care of that. Now, shoo,  shoo.

The children exit. Jim is about to put down the diary whe his curiosity gets the better of him. Making sure he's  unobserved, he sits down on a box, opens the book, starts read. As his brows wrinkle with concern:
The wind is howling, the trees swaying. The lights are on the kitchen. CAMERA MOVES UP to the open kitchen window.

The family, in overcoats, is huddled around the kitchen t finishing dinner. Gussie, in overcoat and muffler, is cle the dishes away. Jim, a sober look on his face, rises, ta a steaming kettle from the stove.
Where are you going?
To shave.
Tonight??
While I can still trust myself with  a razor. At six o'clock in the morning  I'd probably cut my throat. Goodnight.
Jim abruptly exits. Muriel looks after him with concern.
Jim, in his pajamas and overcoat is shaving. After a few  moments Muriel, in her nightgown and overcoat, enters the scene.
Excuse...

She takes her toothbrush and opens the cabinet, Jim  automatically moving around back of it in their previousl established pattern. As Muriel puts the paste on her brus replaces the tube, shuts the cabinet and starts to brush teeth, Jim uncomfortably moves back to his original posit
Excuse...
Muriel, do you have to do that now?!
There's no need to be so irritable  just because you have to shave at  night.
I'm not irritable!
Well, you're certainly something!  You haven't said a civil word all  evening.
Sometimes a man doesn't feel like  talking.
(solicitously) What is it, dear? Something down at  the office?
No.
Have you got the new slogan for  "Wham"?
It's not due yet!
Well, it's something. You're certainly  upset about something. I can always  tell.
I'm not upset. (going back to shaving;  with studied unconcern) It's just that I don't happen to  approve of falsehood and deception.  Particularly in my own wife.
What are you talking about?
(same) Oh, nothing. It's just that I  distinctly remember your telling me  you gave back Bill's fraternity pin  fifteen years ago.
Muriel looks at him, puzzled.
Well, did you or didn't you?
Did I, or didn't I what?
Give it back to him.
Of course I did. If I said I did, I  did.
(suddenly Sam Spade) Then perhaps you'd have the goodness  to explain how this happened to fall  out of your jewel box?
He takes the pin out of his pocket and hands it to her. M takes the pin, looks at it sentimentally. Suddenly she lo at Jim and bursts out laughing.
What's so funny?
You! You're jealous! You're standing  there with your face full of soap  and you're jealous.
(angrily) If you were so crazy about the guy,  why didn't you marry him?!
(beginning to be a  little angry) Because I wasn't in love with him!
(vindictively) That's not what you said in your  diary!
(now really angry) Oh, now you've been reading my diary!
(a little guilty) Well -- it happened to fall open  and... I... happened to look at it.  It... just happened.
I'll just bet!
It's all over the book so why don't  you admit it? You were in love with  Bill Cole!
Don't be absurd! Of course I was in  love with Bill. In those days I was  in love with a new man every week.
Then why did you marry me?

I'm beginning to wonder! (exploding) Maybe it was those big cow eyes of  yours or that ridiculous hole in  your chin! Maybe I knew that some  day you'd bring me out to this thirty- eight thousand dollar icebox with a  dried-up trout stream and no windows!  Or maybe I just happened to fall in  love with you -- but for heaven's  sake, don't ask me why!
Muriel stalks out of the bathroom. Jim looks after her,  thoughtfully starts to dry his face.
Jim enters. Muriel stands with her back to him angrily wi the clock. Jim noisily clears his throat. No reaction.
(tentatively) ...Muriel?
No reaction.
...Honey?
No reaction.
Would it do any good to say I'm sorry?
I don't know.
Jim gently turns her around facing him.
Well -- I am. I acted like a schoolboy  and I'm sorry.
Muriel looks at Jim. Finally she smiles.
Oh, Jim!
She goes into his arms and they kiss intimately. As their lips part:
(dreamily) Why don't you take the soap out of  your ears?
(same) Why do I love you so much?
Jim again kisses her tenderly, warmly.
(breathless) Darling, it's awfully late.
Jim kisses her again, a little more ardently.
(same) Maybe you ought to go down and lock  the doors.
(kissing her ear) What for? The windows are all open  anyway.
(as he starts to kiss  her again) Jim, you have to get up at six  o'clock.
(considers; logic  prevails; brief sigh) Yes, I guess so.
(reluctantly) Goodnight, dear.
(same) Goodnight.
Each gets into his own bed, still wearing the overcoats.

INSERT JIM'S COST CHART - The house now wavers at $37,000 As Jim and Muriel still try to stem the tide, the group t is pushing the house ever upward includes all of the prev people connected with the house and -- in addition --plum painters, landscape gardeners, etc. Over this, and across the scene flutter more bills, more extras.
And so the days sped by -- and the  bills -- and the extras -- and as  the house approached forty thousand  dollars, Jim approached his deadline  for the new slogan. It was almost a  photo finish.
It is raining. The lights are on in the buildings.
Mary is attending to some detail work as the door opens a Jim enters, disturbed. Mary looks at him questioningly.
You'd better send out for coffee and  sandwiches,... It looks like an all  night session.
(concerned) What did he say?
(wearily, seating  himself at desk) Tomorrow morning.
(sighs) Well, I guess you'll just have to  dream something up -- good or bad.
I rather got the impression it had  better be good.
(raised eyebrow) Oh.

He picks up a pencil, nibbles on it thoughtfully. The sil in the room is broken only by the patter of raindrops on window. It strikes a note in Jim's subconscious. He swive around in his chair and stares soberly out the window.
(ruminatively, almost  to himself) Funny how you look forward to the  little things. Rain, for instance.
Mary looks at him curiously. He turns to her.

For a month now, I guess I've been  looking forward to the first rainy  night at the house. (looks at Muriel's  picture) Big blazing fire. Muriel knitting.  Me in my new smoking jacket... with  my pipe and slippers, reading my  paper... (sighs) Oh, well.
As he starts to work.

Note: The house is painted and almost completely furnishe A hard rain beats on the windows. There is a blazing fire the fireplace. Muriel, in a warm bathrobe, sits near it,  comfortably knitting. In fact, the scene is exactly the o Jim has just described, except that the man with slippers pipe and smoking jacket, reading the paper, is Bill Cole. Near the fire, Bill's rain-drenched jacket, shirt and sho are hanging up to dry. The cozy tranquillity is broken by sharp RINGING of the front doorbell.
(with relief) Thank heavens! The children.
(rising) Stay put. You look too comfortable.
The CAMERA FOLLOWS Bill to the front door. He opens it. A man in raincoat and boots stands there in the pouring, dr rain. The man enters as Bill struggles to get the door sh against the wind.
Whew! What a night! I'm Jones, from  down the road. Just came over to  tell you your kids are all right,  Mr. Blandings.
Oh, I'm not Mr. Blandings. Cole's  the name, Bill Cole.
He sees Jones' doubtful look at the smoking jacket, feels explanation is necessary.
Friend of the family. Wet clothes.  Just came in out of the rain.
Muriel walks into scene. Jones takes in the bathrobe, aga looks skeptically at Bill.
I'm Mrs. Blandings.
How do. Mrs. Williams just called.  Says your phone's out of order. Wanted  me to tell you the water's rising  and they've got the bridge roped  off. Girls'll spend the night over  at her place.
Thank you. I was beginning to get  concerned. Can I make you a cup of  tea?
No, thanks. Better be gettin' back  'fore I have to swim for it. 'Night,  Mrs. Blandings. (to Bill) 'Night, Mr. Bl--
(weak smile) Cole. Bill Cole. Friend of the family.  Just came in out of the rain.
(uncertainly) Well -- 'Night.
Goodnight... and thanks so much.
The door is opened with a terrific swirl of wind and rain Jones exits as Muriel and Bill push the door against the  wind, finally getting it shut.
That's fine. No bridge. How do I get  back to Lansdale?
(simply) You'll just have to spend the night  right here.
As they start back into the living room:
Muriel, really! With your husband in  New York and your children away --  think of my reputation.
(smile) Don't worry, Snow White, you'll be  as pure and unsullied in the morning  as you were the night before.
(with resignation) That's the story of my life.
Muriel pokes the dying fire, looks up thoughtfully.
Poor Jim, he sounded so worried  before. I certainly hope he comes up  with something.
Don't worry about the man who gave  the world "When you've got the whim,  say Wham!"-- This well will never  run dry.

The CAMERA COMES IN ON a package of cigarettes. A finger  impatiently rips open what is left of the package, disclo that it is empty. The ANGLE WIDENS to reveal a tired,  disheveled Jim. Disgusted, he fishes the most likely butt from a tray littered with them. With considerable difficu he manages to light it, only to burn his nose. Impatientl stamping out the butt he rises, stretches, walks to the  window, pulls up the shade. Early morning sunlight floods the room. He turns off a standing lamp, looks thoughtfull out the window, suddenly gets an idea. Turning, he snaps fingers. Mary, who is asleep on the desk, her head restin on her elbows, raises her head, opens a sleepy eye.
(selling; a note of  desperation in his  voice) "Compare the price, compare the slice,  Take our advice -- Buy Wham!"

Mary critically shakes her head "no", closes her eye. Jim wearily throws himself down on the couch, absently toys w his already loosened tie. He pulls it up over his nose,  throwing the balance over the top of his head. Suddenly h reacts, snaps his fingers. Mary opens a sleepy eye.
"If you'd buy better ham. You'd better  buy Wham!"
It's Boyle Petroleum. "If you'd buy  better oil, You'd better buy Boyle."

Her eye closes. Jim sinks back with defeat, his hand drop over the edge of the couch. It encounters a crumpled piec of paper, earlier work. He smoothes the paper, scans it,  kind of likes it. He gets up, comes over, snaps fingers.  Mary looks up.
"This little pig went to market As  meek and as mild as a lamb. He smiled  in his tracks When they slipped him  the axe He knew he'd turn out to be  Wham!"
A long silent look passes between them.
(quietly) "...knew he'd turn out to be Wham!"
He suddenly and angrily gathers all his papers, slams the into the wastebasket.

(rising panic) It's gone! I've lost my touch! Maybe  I never had a touch! Maybe "Whim Say  Wham" was an accident! Who knows? I  can't think any more! All I've got  on my mind is a house with an eighteen  thousand dollar mortgage, and bills,  and extras, and antiques, and -- and -- (dejected) I don't know... I don't know.

Mary looks at him sympathetically, doesn't quite know wha to say. As the CAMERA MOVES to a CLOSE SHOT of the emotio distraught Jim, his eyes go to a large photograph on his  desk of Muriel and the children. He picks it up, looks at with affection. Suddenly he gets an idea. Rising with  determination he puts on his coat and starts for the door
(startled) Where are you going?
Home, to get some sleep -- and I'd  advise you to do the same.
But -- but you haven't --
Suppose I haven't! This isn't the  only job in town!
But -- but -- what'll I tell Mr.  Dascomb?
(sharply) You just tell him to -- to -- (with finality) You just tell him!
He exits.

It is an especially beautiful, sunshiny morning. A rural- looking taxi deposits a weary Jim, who pays the driver. A the cab drives off, Jim looks speculatively at Simms' car which is parked there, yawns, stretches, opens the door a enters. Under this a slightly sour underscoring of "Home The Range."
As Jim comes into the foyer, he sees Muriel, in nightgown and robe, talking to Mr. Simms. She holds the rolled-up v of blueprints that went into building the house.
'Morning, dear.
(going to him;  solicitously) Darling, you must be exhausted. How  did it go?
Fine. Fine.
They kiss.
(obliquely) Is... everything all right?
(unenthusiastic) Everything's fine. (still in embrace;  looking up) Hello, Simms, what brings you out  with the morning dew?
Just dropped by to check the  blueprints. Some extras came in from  Retch this morning and there're a  couple of things I thought we ought  to go over together.
(arms still around  Muriel; unconcerned) Really. What are they?
Well, let's see. (thumbing through  sheets) Few little things here, all right, I  guess. "Mortising five butts -- a  dollar sixty-eight."
Let's not quibble about that. A man's  entitled to mortise a few butts now  and then.
(next sheet) Extra nails and screws -- three  dollars, eighty-nine cents.
Petty larceny, but let him get away  with it.
Now there's one here I frankly don't  understand. Ah, here we are. (reads) "Changes in closet, twelve hundred  and forty-seven dollars." Did you  authorize that?
Well, we probably told him to -- (reacting) Twelve hundred and what?!
Forty-seven dollars. Changes in  closet. (hands bill to Jim)
(explosively) Who does he think we are! (looks at bill; very  businesslike) What's this notation: "Refer to Detail  Sheet Number one thirty-five?"
(indicating blueprints) Far as I remember, that would be  something in the back of the house.  Let's just take a look.
As he unrolls the blueprints, Jim looks suspiciously at  Muriel. She seems a little nervous.
Ah, here we are. It isn't a closet  at all. It's off the back pantry...  Mrs. Blandings' little flower sink.
Oh... Mrs. Blandings' little flower  sink.
(to Muriel) You didn't authorize any changes,  did you?
(defensively) Well... they certainly weren't  changes.
What -- have -- you -- done?
(speaking rapidly a  little confused) I haven't done anything! And what I  did was... just nothing at all.
What -- have -- you -- done?!

Well -- (rattling off) All I did was one day I saw four  pieces of flagstone left over from  the porch that were just going to be  thrown away because nobody wanted  them and I asked Mr. Retch if he  wouldn't just put them down on the  floor of the flower sink and poke a  little cement between the cracks and  give me a nice stone floor where it  might be wet with flowers and things.  That was absolutely all I did.
During the above speech Simms sinks into a chair, puts hi head in his hands and closes his eyes, a fact that isn't  lost on Jim.
That's all you did?
Absolutely. Just four little pieces  of flagstone.
(to Muriel; wearily) Did you by any chance authorize a  drain?

(verge of tears) Of course I didn't. All I said was I  wanted a nice stone floor and Mr.  Retch was just as nice as could be  and said, "You're the doctor," and  that's all anybody ever said to  anybody about anything.
Jim takes a deep breath, turns to Simms.
...Well?

(sigh; plunging in) All right, I think I can tell you  what happened. First, the carpenters  had to rip up the flooring that was  already laid. Those planks run under  the whole width of the pantry, so  Retch had to knock the bottom out of  the pantry wall to get at them.
Jim and Muriel - Jim looks at Muriel as though he were  premeditating first-degree murder. She averts his gaze. O this:

Then he had to chop out the tops of  the joists under the flower sink  space to make room for a cradle. I  guess he bought some iron straps and  fastened them to a big pan to give  him something to hold the cement.  What with that added load on the  weakened joists, I'll bet he had to  put a lally column down there for  support, too.
It was just four little pieces of  flagstone, and I only ---
Quiet!
GROUP SHOT - During the following speech we see Bill Cole in Jim's pajamas and robe come down the stairs and enter room. Jim and Muriel are not aware of his presence.

Well, the main soil pipe runs under  there on wall brackets, so Retch had  to get his plumbing man back to take  out a section so he could get that  cradle set. I guess that meant he  had to change the pitch of the soil  pipe from one end of the house to  the other. (looks up) 'Morning, Mr. Cole.
'Morning. Hello, Jim.
(turning) Hello, Bill.
Jim turns away, reacts, suddenly turns back to Bill, taki in the pajamas and robe. A little shocked but unwilling t believe the implication of what he sees, he looks to Muri for an explanation.
(lamely) The bridge was roped off and Bill  had to stay last night.
(cheerily) Slept like a rock.
I'm delighted.
Jim looks at Bill, then back at Muriel.

(clearing his throat) And then, of course, there are hot  and cold water pipes hooked to the  joists right under that pantry. They  go up to the wing bathroom on the  second floor, and I'll bet my bottom  dollar he had to relocate them.
THREE SHOT - Jim, Muriel and Bill. Jim turns to listen bu finds himself looking speculatively at Muriel and Bill.

And I guess the electrician had to  rip out about sixty feet of armored  cable between the main panel and the  junction box by the oil burner,  including the two hundred twenty  volt cable that goes to the stove.
FULL SHOT - Gussie appears in the doorway in raincoat,  carrying umbrella.
'Morning, everybody. Whew! What a  night!
Where have you been?
Lansdale. Couldn't get back across  the bridge.
You... weren't here last night?
They weren't letting anybody across  that bridge, Mr. Blandings. (to Muriel) I passed the girls over at the  Williams. They'll be along any minute.
As Jim reacts:
(quickly) Thank you, Gussie. You'd better get  breakfast started.
As Gussie exits, Muriel turns to Simms.
Where were we?
We were at the two hundred twenty  volt cable that goes to the stove.
Just a minute. (looks at Bill, then  at Muriel) You mean the children weren't here  last night either?
How could they be, dear? The bridge  was closed.
I just came across it.
Well, it was closed last night.
(pointedly) It's open now!
Embarrassed pause.
(attempt at breeziness) If you'll all excuse me -- I -- I  think I'll just go up and slip into  something a little more comfortable.
Bill exits. Another pause. Simms, aware of the tension, w to get out of there.
(rapidly) Well, that's about the size of it --
Through Simms' speech, Jim looks darkly at Muriel.
-- except that Retch had to repair  the pantry wall and that meant getting  a plasterer back. And of course, he  couldn't have broken through that  wall --
All right, Simms, all right. We'll  take care of it.
(preparing to exit) I'll admit it's a little steep. But  I'll try to get Retch to knock a  hundred dollars off the bill. If I  can't get that, I'll certainly try  for seventy-five.
Fine.
If he doesn't go for seventy-five,  I'll take a stab at fifty.
You do that.
(at the door) Anyway, I'm almost sure we can get  twenty-five.
There is no answer.
(lamely) Well. Good day.
He leaves. There is a deadly pause.
(carefully) Now dear, you're upset, you've got a  lot of things on your mind --
(with dangerous calm) Muriel, there's only one thing on my  mind -- This house -- and how fast  we can get rid of it!
That's not what you're thinking.

Maybe it's not. Maybe I'm thinking I  was once a happy man! (the martyr) I didn't have a closet, I didn't  have three bathrooms, but I did have  my sanity, a few dollars in the bank,  two children who loved me and a wife  I could trust!
That's a fine thing to say!
I also had a job at Danton and  Bascomb, something I don't happen to  have at the moment!
Jim!
That's right, I've resigned! We're  starting all over again! From scratch!  And without this house!
(near tears) You love this house!
I hate it!
In the b.g. Mr. Tesander enters, cap in hand, stands ther nervous and embarrassed.
You don't mean that.

Every word of it! Anybody who builds  a house today is crazy! The minute  you start, they put you on the list.  The All-American Sucker list!  Everywhere you turn they've got a  hand in your pocket. If you take out  their hands, they find more pockets! (explosively) It's a conspiracy, I tell you, a  conspiracy against every man and  woman who want a home of their own!  Against every boy and girl who were  ever in love!
Tesander clears his throat. Jim turns.
(sharply) What do you want?!
A slight embarrassed pause. Then:
(shyly) Well, Mr. Blandings, there's a matter  of twelve dollars and eighty-six  cents.

(with a wild gleam) Twelve dollars and eighty-six cents!  Why be a piker, Mr. Tesander? (emptying pockets) Take everything I've got! Spread it  out among your pals! (advancing toward the  bewildered Tesander) Wouldn't Retch like a little  something? Maybe Zucca could use my  new dinner jacket? It's open house,  Mr. Tesander! Help yourself! If this  isn't enough I'll come over to your  place and do some odd chores. Maybe  I can mow your lawn or scratch your  back!
(simply) You don't understand, Mr. Blandings.  This twelve dollars and eighty-six  cents -- you don't owe me, I owe  you.
There is a momentary pause.
...W-what was that?
(taking out money) Found I overcharged you. Almost three  feet.
He hands the money to Jim, who stares at it blankly.
Better count it. I think it's all  there.
Jim looks haplessly at Muriel, sheepish, guilty.
Thank you very much, Mr. Tesander.
Well, I guess I'd better be gettin'  along. (looking around) Sure got a pretty place here. (at door; pauses;  looks back) I'll tell Mr. Zucca about the dinner  jacket.
Jim and Muriel look at each other a little sheepishly.
As Tesander is about to exit, Bill, dressed, starts down stairs.
Oh, Mr. Tesander -- could you give  me a lift to town?
Yep.
Be right with you.
(concerned) What did you mean before about losing  your job? Will we really have to  sell the house?
(miserable) I don't know, dear... I don't know.
Bill enters.
In case anyone's interested, I'm  leaving for town. (for Jim's benefit) If you want to count the silverware,  I'll wait.
(sheepishly) Bill, be patient with me. Maybe one  of these days I'll grow up.
(to Muriel) What happened to him?
Twelve dollars and eighty-six cents.
Mind if I say something?
Jim and Muriel look at him curiously.

You know, I've kind of been the voice  of doom about this whole project.  Every step of the way I was firmly  convinced you were getting fleeced,  bilked, rooked, flimflammed and  generally taken to the cleaners. And  maybe you were. Maybe it cost you a  whole lot more than you thought it  would. Maybe there were times when  you wished you'd never started the  whole thing. But when I look around  and see what you two have here -- I  don't know. (pause) Maybe there are some things you should  buy with your heart and not with  your head. Maybe those are the things  that really count... See you around.
As Bill turns and leaves, the outer door is heard opening and the kids appear. There is an exchange of "Hi's" as th pass.
'Morning, everybody!
(surprised) Hi, Dad! How come you're not at the  office?
(a look at Muriel) I'm on a... kind of a vacation.
You mean you got fired?
Well, not exactly, I --
We'll discuss it later.
Gussie's head appears from the kitchen.
(brightly) Come and get it! Breakfast everybody.
Good! I'm starving! What are we  having, Gussie?
Orange juice, scrambled eggs and you- know-what.
(making a face) Ham?
Not ham -- Wham! (cheerily) If you ain't eatin' Wham, you ain't  eatin' ham!
Gussie's head disappears. CLOSE SHOT - JIM. CLOSE SHOT - Jim.
What did she say?
He reacts with the sudden exhilaration of Balboa first se the Pacific. He snaps his fingers.
Darling, give Gussie a ten dollar  raise!
His eyes light up as he begins to visualize.
INSERT ADVERTISEMENT IN MAGAZINE - It is a picture of Gus smiling, holding a platter with an enormous ham. Under it the simple caption: "IF YOU AIN'T EATIN' WHAM, YOU AIN'T EATIN' HAM!"

THE CAMERA ANGLE WIDENS to disclose Mr. James Blandings  reclining in a hammock on the patio of his Dream House. I the b.g. Muriel is working at her garden, Joan and Betsy  assisting her. Jim reacts with pride and satisfaction as sets the magazine down, takes a long drink of lemonade an picks up a book which he has been reading. As the CAMERA  COMES IN for an EXTREME CLOSE SHOT of Jim we see the titl of the book on the jacket cover. It reads: "MR. BLANDINGS BUILDS HIS DREAM HOUSE"
Jim looks up over the top of the book, directly into the  camera and winks.
(with simple sincerity) Drop in and see us sometime.
As the CAMERA PULLS AWAY to a LONG SHOT tableau of the  Blandings and their Dream House, we:
